This detailed plot summary is based solely on the provided text of "A Doll's House."

**Act I**

The play opens on Christmas Eve in the comfortably furnished home of Nora and Torvald Helmer. Nora enters, humming happily, with Christmas parcels. She secretly eats macaroons, which her husband, Torvald, has forbidden. Torvald, who works as a lawyer, soon emerges from his study, playfully calling Nora his "little lark" and "little squirrel" and teasing her about being a "spendthrift." He gives her money for Christmas, though he cautions against excessive spending, emphasizing his strong belief that a home life should be free of debt and borrowing. Nora reveals that Torvald is about to become manager of the Bank after the New Year, which will bring them more financial security.

Nora's old school friend, Christine Linde, arrives, looking dejected. Nora initially struggles to recognize her due to her changed appearance. Christine reveals that she is a widow who has endured many years of hardship, working tirelessly to support her sick, bedridden mother and two younger brothers. Now that her mother has died and her brothers are self-sufficient, Christine feels "unspeakably empty" and seeks regular office work. Nora promises to speak to Torvald about getting Christine a position at the Bank.

Nora, eager to prove she is not just a "child," confides a major secret to Christine. Years ago, when Torvald was gravely ill and doctors said he needed to go to Italy to recover, Nora secretly borrowed two hundred and fifty pounds. She did this because Torvald's principles forbade borrowing, and she couldn't bring herself to reveal the severity of his illness to him. She made everyone believe the money came from her dying father. Since then, she has been secretly working odd jobs like needlework and copying, and economizing from her household allowance (which Torvald believes she wastes) to pay back the quarterly interest and installments on the loan. She proudly states that she "saved Torvald's life."

During this conversation, Dr. Rank, a close family friend, arrives and goes to speak with Torvald. Shortly after, a lawyer named Krogstad also arrives to see Torvald on "Bank business." Mrs. Linde reacts with visible shock and fear upon seeing Krogstad, revealing she knew him years ago. Dr. Rank later comments on Krogstad, describing him as "morally diseased" and confirming he works at the Bank.

After Krogstad's meeting with Torvald, Krogstad confronts Nora. He reveals that Torvald intends to dismiss him from his post at the Bank and suggests that Mrs. Linde is being hired to take his place. He demands that Nora use her influence to persuade Torvald to keep him on. Nora denies having such influence. Krogstad then reveals he knows Nora's secret: the loan she took out for Torvald's recovery. He reminds her that she forged her father's signature on the bond, dating it three days after her father had actually died. Krogstad explains that he himself committed a similar "indiscretion" (forgery) in the past, which ruined his reputation, and he is desperate to reclaim his good name for his sons. He warns Nora that if he loses his position, she will lose hers with him, threatening to expose her secret to Torvald.

Nora is horrified but attempts to dismiss Krogstad's threats. When Torvald returns, Nora tries to hide Krogstad's visit. Torvald, however, immediately suspects Krogstad was there to plead for his job. He lectures Nora about Krogstad's moral corruption, particularly his forgery, stating that such "an atmosphere of lies infects and poisons the whole life of a home" and that almost everyone who has "gone to the bad early in life has had a deceitful mother." He explicitly forbids Nora from pleading Krogstad's cause, claiming he feels "physically ill" in the company of such dishonest people. Nora is left alone, terrified by Torvald's words, and pushes her children away, fearing she might "deprave" or "poison" them.

**Act II**

The next day, Christmas Day, Nora is visibly anxious, checking the letterbox for Krogstad's potential communication. She asks the Nurse if her children would forget her if she "went away altogether," and inquires about the Nurse's own experience of leaving her child for work, a decision the Nurse states was necessary for her to take the position as Nora's nurse.

Mrs. Linde arrives to help Nora mend her Neapolitan fisher-girl costume for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. During their conversation, Nora reveals that Dr. Rank is suffering from a terminal spinal disease, inherited from his father's "excesses," and will likely die soon. Mrs. Linde, suspecting that Dr. Rank might be the one who lent Nora the money, advises Nora to end her association with him. Nora vehemently denies Rank lent her the money, stating he had no funds at the time. She then admits she needs to "make an end of it" with "the other one" (Krogstad) behind Torvald's back.

Torvald returns, and Nora desperately tries to convince him to keep Krogstad employed, using affectionate pleas and promising to dance beautifully for him. Torvald refuses, reiterating Krogstad's moral failings and, more importantly, admitting that Krogstad's overly familiar address ("Helmer, old fellow") makes him uncomfortable and would undermine his authority at the Bank. Despite Nora's frantic pleas, Torvald immediately dispatches a letter via the maid, dismissing Krogstad.

Overwhelmed, Nora cries out, but Torvald assures her that he is "man enough to take everything upon myself" if any trouble arises. Nora is briefly horrified by this statement, but quickly recovers, insisting he won't have to. He then urges her to practice her Tarantella, promising to help her and instructing her not to worry about anything until after the ball.

Dr. Rank arrives and, after some conversation, reveals to Nora that he has received "absolute certainty" of his impending death, which he describes as a consequence of his father's sins. He states he will send Nora a card with a black cross on it when the end is near and does not want Torvald in his sickroom, as Torvald dislikes anything "ugly." Nora, still contemplating seeking financial help, hints at needing a "tremendously big favour" from him. Misinterpreting her hints, Rank confesses his deep love for her and his willingness to sacrifice his life for her. Nora is shocked and repulsed by his declaration, rejecting his offer of help.

The maid then brings Nora Krogstad's card. Krogstad has come to the house through the back stairs. Nora quickly bolts Helmer's study door to prevent him from interfering and confronts Krogstad. Krogstad reveals he knows Torvald has dismissed him. He tells Nora he isn't going to accuse her but demands to be reinstated in a higher position at the Bank, as it is his chance to restore his reputation. He states he has a letter for Torvald detailing everything, and he will not take it back. He warns Nora that any desperate action on her part, such as running away or "something worse," would be futile, as he would still have Torvald in his power. As Krogstad leaves, he drops the incriminating letter into the Helmers' locked letterbox.

Nora, in despair, shows Mrs. Linde the letter and confesses to forging her father's signature. She declares that "a wonderful thing is going to happen!" but also that it "mustn't happen, not for all the world." She asks Christine to be her witness that she alone committed the act, in case she goes "out of her mind" or "anything else should happen to me." Mrs. Linde, understanding Krogstad's motivations, rushes out to try and intercept Krogstad, believing she can talk him into retrieving the letter. Nora, desperate to buy time, tells Torvald she needs his help practicing the Tarantella and makes him promise not to open any letters until after the ball. She feels she has "thirty-one hours to live" until her secret is exposed.

**Act III**

Later that night, after the fancy-dress ball, Mrs. Linde is waiting for Krogstad in the Helmers' living room. When Krogstad arrives, she reveals her true reasons for breaking off their engagement years ago: she had to provide for her sick mother and brothers, and his future seemed bleak. Now that she is alone, she feels her life is "unspeakably empty" and proposes that they "join forces," offering to be a mother to his children. Krogstad is deeply moved and overjoyed, feeling he can now "clear myself in the eyes of the world." He remembers the letter he sent to Helmer and offers to retrieve it. However, Mrs. Linde stops him, insisting that the "unhappy secret must be disclosed" so that Torvald and Nora can have "a complete understanding between them," which is impossible with ongoing "concealment and falsehood." Krogstad agrees and leaves, expressing his profound happiness.

Torvald and Nora return from the ball. Torvald is flushed with excitement, praising Nora's dancing and beauty, and expressing his possessive desire for her. Nora, however, is tense and distant. Mrs. Linde says goodnight and leaves, having confirmed to Nora that she spoke to Krogstad and that Nora "must tell your husband all about it." Nora responds that she "knew it" and "now I know what I must do."

After Mrs. Linde leaves, Torvald tries to rekindle his intimacy with Nora, expressing his longing for her. Their conversation is interrupted by Dr. Rank, who has also returned from the ball. Rank, who has drunk too much, makes cryptic remarks about death and enjoyment. He reveals that he has sent his calling cards to the house, one of which has a black cross on it, signifying his impending death and his final farewell. He then leaves.

Torvald decides to clear the letterbox. Despite Nora's frantic attempts to stop him, he opens it. He finds Dr. Rank's cards with the black crosses, which Nora confirms is Rank's way of announcing he will soon "shut himself up and die." Torvald expresses sadness for Rank but quickly shifts to his own feelings, stating that Rank's death will bring him and Nora "quite upon each other now." He fantasizes about Nora being in danger so he could "risk my life's blood, and everything, for your sake."

Nora insists that Torvald read his letters. He retreats to his study. Moments later, he bursts out, holding Krogstad's letter. He is furious, calling Nora a "miserable creature," "hypocrite," "liar," and "criminal." He denounces her actions as a reflection of her father's "want of principle" and declares she has "destroyed all my happiness" and "ruined all my future," as Krogstad now has power over him. He states that he must maintain appearances, and while Nora will remain in his house, he will not allow her to raise the children, fearing she will corrupt them. He declares their happiness is over, and now only "the remains, the fragments, the appearance" matter.

Suddenly, the front doorbell rings. The maid brings in another letter for Nora. Torvald seizes it and reads it. His mood instantly shifts to one of overwhelming joy. Krogstad has sent back the bond and his letters, expressing regret and repentance due to "a happy change in his life." Torvald tears up all the incriminating papers and burns them, declaring, "It’s all over! It’s all over! We are saved, Nora!" He embraces Nora, assuring her he has forgiven her, knowing she acted "out of love for me." He calls her his "womanly helplessness," his "frightened little singing-bird," and promises to protect and guide her, stating that she has become "both wife and child to him."

Nora, however, has changed into her everyday dress. She calmly asks Torvald to sit down for a "serious conversation," stating that for eight years, they have never truly talked. She reveals that she has never understood him, nor he her, and that their marriage has been like a "playroom" where she was his "doll-wife," just as she was her father's "doll-child." She accuses him and her father of committing a "great sin" against her by preventing her from making anything of her life. She declares she has never been happy, only "merry."

Nora states that she must leave him to "educate myself" and understand herself as an individual. Torvald tries to forbid her, reminding her of her "most sacred duties" to her husband and children. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself. She rejects the notion that she is primarily a wife and mother, asserting that she is, "before all else," a "reasonable human being" who must learn to think for herself. She questions the law, which she finds "foolish," for not allowing a daughter to spare her dying father anxiety or a wife to save her husband's life.

Torvald calls her ill and delirious, and accuses her of no longer loving him. Nora confirms that she does not. She explains that when the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for—his willingness to sacrifice his honor for her—did not happen, she realized he was not the man she thought he was. She saw that his fear was for his own reputation, not for her. She concludes that she has been living with a "strange man" for eight years.

Nora takes off her wedding ring, gives it back to Torvald, and asks for her own in return, declaring that there must be "perfect freedom on both sides." She states she will not see the children, believing they are in better hands. She rejects any offer of help or money from Torvald, calling him a "stranger." She states that the "most wonderful thing of all" would be for both of them to be so changed that their life together would be a "real wedlock," but she no longer believes in wonderful things. She bids him goodbye and leaves the house, shutting the door behind her. Torvald sinks into a chair, calling her name, then looks around the empty room, a hope flashing across his mind: "The most wonderful thing of all—?" The sound of the outer door shutting echoes, signifying Nora's definitive departure.

Alice's Adventures in Wonderland begins with Alice sitting by her sister on a riverbank, feeling bored and sleepy. Her sister is reading a book without pictures or conversations, which Alice finds useless. Suddenly, a White Rabbit with pink eyes runs by, pulls a watch from its waistcoat-pocket, and exclaims, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Driven by curiosity, Alice follows the Rabbit down a large rabbit-hole without considering how she will get out.

The rabbit-hole plunges into a very deep well, allowing Alice ample time to observe her surroundings. She notices cupboards, bookshelves, maps, and pictures adorning the sides. She grabs a jar labelled "ORANGE MARMALADE" but finds it empty; she carefully places it in a cupboard to avoid hitting anyone below. As she continues to fall, she speculates about her depth and location, eventually growing sleepy and dozing off, dreaming of her cat, Dinah.

She suddenly lands on a heap of sticks and dry leaves, unhurt. She finds herself in a long, low hall, lit by lamps. All the doors are locked. She discovers a tiny golden key on a solid glass table. The key is too small for the large door locks, but then she spots a low curtain concealing a little door, about fifteen inches high. The golden key fits this lock. Alice opens the door and sees a beautiful garden but cannot fit through, wishing she could "shut up like a telescope."

Returning to the table, she finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After prudently checking it's not marked "poison," she tastes the delicious liquid (a mix of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast) and quickly finishes it. She immediately begins shrinking, becoming ten inches high – the perfect size for the small door. However, she realizes she left the golden key on the table, which is now too high to reach. She cries in frustration.

Her gaze falls on a small cake under the table, marked "EAT ME." She decides to eat it, hoping it will change her size again. After eating a bit, she remains the same size, which she finds dull given the day's unusual events. She finishes the cake.

Upon finishing the cake, Alice grows enormously, becoming over nine feet high, her head striking the hall's roof. She grabs the key but is now too large for the garden door. She sits down and weeps profusely, creating a large pool of tears that fills half the hall. The White Rabbit returns, splendidly dressed, carrying gloves and a fan, muttering about the Duchess. Alice tries to ask for help, but the Rabbit is startled, drops its items, and scurries away.

Alice picks up the fan and gloves. As she fans herself, she begins to shrink again, realizing the fan is the cause. She quickly drops it, narrowly avoiding disappearing entirely, and finds herself about two feet high. The little door is still shut, and the key is out of reach on the table. She slips and falls into the pool of tears she created, finding herself swimming among other creatures, including a Mouse.

She tries to converse with the Mouse, asking for directions out of the pool. When she attempts French ("Où est ma chatte?"), the Mouse is terrified. Alice apologizes, explaining she forgot it didn't like cats, then mentions her own cat, Dinah, which further offends the Mouse because Dinah catches mice. After Alice also mentions dogs, the Mouse, trembling with anger, agrees to tell its history only if they reach the shore. The pool becomes crowded with birds and animals that have fallen in (a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, an Eaglet, etc.). Alice leads them to the bank.

On the bank, all the wet creatures discuss how to get dry. The Mouse, taking authority, attempts to dry them by reciting a dull history of William the Conqueror, which fails. The Dodo then proposes a "Caucus-race," where everyone runs randomly until dry. After about half an hour, they are indeed dry, and the Dodo declares everyone has won and must have prizes. Alice provides a box of comfits as prizes for everyone. The Dodo, taking Alice's thimble, solemnly presents it back to her as her prize.

The Mouse then attempts to tell its "long and a sad tale" (a pun Alice misunderstands as referring to its tail's literal length and shape). The story is a poem about a trial between Fury and a mouse. Alice, distracted by the Mouse's tail, is not paying attention, which angers the Mouse. Alice tries to apologize, but the Mouse, easily offended, walks away when Alice misunderstands "knot" for "not." Alice calls after it, promising not to mention cats or dogs, but the Mouse refuses to return. Alice then mentions her cat, Dinah, and how good she is at catching mice and birds. This causes all the birds to flee in terror, leaving Alice alone and crying again.

The White Rabbit returns, searching frantically for his fan and gloves, fearing the Duchess. He mistakes Alice for his housemaid, Mary Ann, and orders her to fetch them from his house. Alice complies, finds the house (labeled "W. RABBIT"), and goes inside. In a room, she finds the fan and gloves, along with an unlabeled bottle. She drinks from the bottle, hoping to grow, and indeed she does, quickly filling the entire room, with one arm out a window and one foot up the chimney.

The Rabbit returns, calling for Mary Ann. Unable to open the door due to Alice's size, he decides to enter through the window. Alice snatches at him through the window, causing a shriek and sounds of broken glass. The Rabbit then calls for "Pat" (a Lizard), ordering him to remove Alice's arm from the window. More broken glass sounds follow as Alice snatches again. The creatures outside decide to send Bill the Lizard down the chimney. Alice kicks her foot, sending Bill flying out. The Rabbit then proposes burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set her cat Dinah on them. They resort to throwing pebbles, which turn into cakes. Alice eats one, shrinks, and escapes the house.

Outside, she finds a crowd of animals, including Bill the Lizard, being revived by guinea-pigs. Alice runs into a thick wood, determined to return to her proper size and find the garden. She encounters an enormous puppy, which she distracts with a stick and then escapes from. She then finds a large mushroom. Peering over it, she sees a large blue Caterpillar smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you?_" Alice explains her identity crisis due to constant size changes. The Caterpillar is unimpressed and dismisses her concerns. After a tense exchange, Alice grows irritated and tries to leave, but the Caterpillar calls her back, telling her to "Keep your temper" and promising "something important." It then tells her she is changed and asks her to recite "You are old, Father William," which Alice does, but the words are altered into a nonsensical version. The Caterpillar criticizes her. When asked her desired size, Alice says she'd like to be a "little larger" than three inches, which offends the three-inch Caterpillar. The Caterpillar then crawls away, instructing her that "One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter"—referring to the mushroom.

Alice breaks off a piece of mushroom from each side. She nibbles one piece and shrinks drastically, her chin hitting her foot. She then eats from the other piece and grows an incredibly long neck, resembling a serpent, rising above the trees. A Pigeon attacks her, screaming "Serpent!" and accusing her of hunting for eggs. Alice insists she is a "little girl," but the Pigeon dismisses this, arguing that if girls eat eggs, they are a kind of serpent. Alice, annoyed, manages to eat from both mushroom pieces until she returns to her normal height. She then finds a tiny house (four feet high) and, recalling her past experiences, eats from the mushroom again to shrink to nine inches before approaching it.

At the tiny house, Alice witnesses a Fish-Footman deliver a croquet invitation from the Queen to a Frog-Footman for the Duchess. The Frog-Footman's nonsensical replies to Alice's questions about entering the house frustrate her. A plate flies out, narrowly missing the Footman's head. Alice, exasperated, opens the door and enters a smoky kitchen. Inside, the Duchess nurses a constantly sneezing and howling baby, while a Cook stirs peppery soup and a Cheshire Cat grins. Alice asks about the Cat's grin, learning it's a "Cheshire cat." The Cook begins throwing kitchenware at the Duchess and baby. The Duchess, after spouting confusing morals, flings the baby at Alice and leaves to play croquet.

Alice struggles to hold the oddly shaped, grunting baby. Outside, she realizes the baby's features are increasingly pig-like. Despite her warnings, the baby fully transforms into a pig. Alice sets it down, and it trots off into the wood. She then encounters the grinning Cheshire Cat again, sitting on a tree branch. Alice asks which way to go. The Cat says it depends on her destination, adding that everyone there is mad, including Alice, and points her towards the March Hare and the Hatter. The Cat then vanishes and reappears twice, eventually fading away completely, leaving only its grin floating in the air, which Alice finds most curious. She continues toward the March Hare's house, shrinking herself slightly with the mushroom to two feet tall as a precaution.

Alice arrives at the March Hare's house, finding the March Hare and the Hatter having a never-ending tea party with a sleeping Dormouse as a cushion. They claim "No room!" but Alice sits down indignantly. They offer wine (which doesn't exist) and then argue about politeness. The Hatter makes a personal remark about Alice's hair, then asks the riddle, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?" but neither he nor the March Hare knows the answer. They engage in a nonsensical debate about language and time. The Hatter reveals they are stuck at perpetually tea-time (six o'clock) because the Queen of Hearts had him sentenced for "murdering the time" during a concert. They constantly move around the table for clean cups.

The March Hare suggests a story. The Dormouse, after being pinched awake, reluctantly tells a confusing story about three sisters living in a "treacle-well" and drawing "treacle" and other things beginning with "M." The Hatter and March Hare frequently interrupt Alice's questions and explanations. Alice becomes fed up with their rudeness and walks away in disgust, noting that they try to put the Dormouse into the teapot. She declares it the "stupidest tea-party" she's ever attended. She finds a door in a tree, enters it, and discovers she's back in the long hall. Using the golden key and the mushroom to adjust her size to about a foot high, she finally enters the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice finds three card gardeners painting white roses red, fearing the Queen's wrath for planting the wrong color tree. The Queen of Hearts arrives with a grand procession of card soldiers, courtiers, royal children, guests (including the White Rabbit), and the Knave of Hearts. Alice refuses to lie down like the gardeners. The Queen, discovering the gardeners' deception, orders their heads chopped off. Alice hides them in a flower-pot, and the soldiers, unable to find them, report that "Their heads are gone." The Queen then invites Alice to play croquet.

The croquet game is chaotic: the ground is uneven, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the arches are doubled-up soldiers who constantly move. The Queen, in a furious temper, repeatedly shouts "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!" and sentences many players to execution, leaving only the King, Queen, and Alice not in custody. Alice, fearing for her own head, sees the grinning Cheshire Cat's head appear in the air. She talks to it, complaining about the game's unfairness. The King, disliking the Cat, orders its removal. The Queen echoes "Off with his head!" The executioner, the King, and the Queen argue about how to behead a head without a body, especially as the Cat's head begins to fade. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, who is fetched from prison. By the time the Duchess arrives, the Cat's head has completely vanished.

The Duchess joins Alice, linking arms and speaking in a much kinder tone, spouting various morals. The Queen reappears, angrily giving the Duchess a choice between her head and leaving. The Duchess vanishes instantly. The Queen, out of breath from ordering so many executions, asks Alice if she's seen the Mock Turtle. The King, meanwhile, secretly pardons all the imprisoned guests. The Queen sends Alice with a Gryphon to find the Mock Turtle and hear its story. The Gryphon assures Alice that the Queen's execution threats are just "fancy" and that "they never executes nobody."

They find the Mock Turtle, sighing sadly. It begins its story by revealing, "Once... I was a real Turtle," then dissolves into sobs. After some time, it continues, describing its schooling in the sea, learning "Reeling and Writhing," "Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils." The Gryphon adds that he learned "Laughing and Grief." Alice asks about their lesson schedule, learning they lessen each day. The Gryphon interrupts, suggesting they talk about games instead of lessons.

The Mock Turtle describes the "Lobster Quadrille," a dance involving lobsters as partners, throwing them out to sea, and somersaults. The Mock Turtle and Gryphon then demonstrate parts of the dance around Alice, singing a song about a whiting and a snail. Alice enjoys the song but is puzzled by the explanation of why whitings have their tails in their mouths (they fell from the sky with lobsters). The Gryphon further explains that "whiting" also refers to something that "does the boots and shoes" under the sea, made of "soles and eels." Alice begins to tell them her own adventures, starting from seeing the White Rabbit. When she recounts her changed recitation of "Father William" for the Caterpillar, the Mock Turtle is intrigued and asks her to repeat another poem. Alice recites "’Tis the voice of the Lobster," but the words are nonsensical. The Mock Turtle demands an explanation, but the Gryphon tells Alice to stop. The Mock Turtle then begins to sing "Turtle Soup," a song praising "Beautiful Soup."

As the Mock Turtle sings, a cry of "The trial’s beginning!" is heard. The Gryphon immediately pulls Alice away, rushing her to the trial, leaving the song unfinished.

Alice and the Gryphon arrive at the trial of the Knave of Hearts, accused of stealing the Queen's tarts. The King and Queen are on their throne, the Knave is in chains, and the White Rabbit serves as the herald. Alice identifies the King as the judge and twelve assorted creatures as the jury, who are busily writing their names on slates to avoid forgetting them. Alice calls them "Stupid things!" and subtly removes Bill the Lizard's squeaky pencil. The White Rabbit reads the accusation: a poem about the Knave stealing the Queen's tarts.

The first witness is the Hatter, who arrives with a teacup and bread-and-butter, claiming he hadn't finished tea. His testimony is rambling and nonsensical, involving the March Hare and Dormouse, and he is accused by the King of having "stolen" his hat (which he merely sells). Alice notices she is growing larger again, causing the Dormouse, seated next to her, to complain. The Queen glares at the Hatter, and the King threatens him with execution. The Hatter continues his confused testimony, denying or forgetting details, and is eventually dismissed. A guinea-pig is suppressed for cheering. The Queen orders the Hatter's head chopped off outside, but he escapes.

The second witness is the Duchess's Cook, who carries a pepper-box, causing everyone to sneeze. She refuses to give evidence. The King cross-examines her, asking what tarts are made of, and she replies "Pepper, mostly." The Dormouse pipes up, saying "Treacle," leading to a chaotic attempt by the Queen to have the Dormouse beheaded and suppressed. During the confusion, the Cook disappears. The King, relieved, calls for the next witness.

The White Rabbit announces the next witness is "Alice!" Alice, forgetting her size, jumps up, knocking over the jury-box and scattering the jurymen. She hastily puts them back, correcting Bill the Lizard who was placed head-down. The King asks what she knows about the business; Alice replies "Nothing." The King initially calls this "important," but the White Rabbit corrects him to "unimportant." The King then reads "Rule Forty-two. _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Everyone looks at Alice, who is now very tall. She refuses to leave, arguing it's not a real rule and was just invented.

The White Rabbit then produces a paper, a set of unsigned verses, found on the prisoner. The King, assuming mischief, declares it proves the Knave's guilt. Alice, now very large and fearless, declares there's "not an atom of meaning in it." The King attempts to interpret the nonsensical poem, trying to link lines to the Knave's actions and the Queen's history (leading to the Queen throwing an inkstand at Bill the Lizard). The King makes a pun, and the court laughs. The Queen demands "Sentence first—verdict afterwards!" Alice vehemently rejects this, calling it "Stuff and nonsense!" The Queen, enraged, shouts "Off with her head!"

Alice, now at her full size, defiantly declares, "Who cares for you? You're nothing but a pack of cards!" At this, the entire pack of cards rises into the air and flies down upon her. Alice screams, half in fright and half in anger, and tries to beat them off.

She then wakes up, finding herself lying on the riverbank with her head in her sister's lap. Her sister is gently brushing dead leaves from her face. Alice tells her sister about her "curious dream." Her sister, after hearing the tale, closes her eyes and imagines Alice's adventures, seeing the White Rabbit, the Mouse, the tea party, the Queen, the pig-baby, the Gryphon, the Lizard's pencil, and the Mock Turtle. She then envisions Alice as a grown woman, sharing these wonderful stories with other children, cherishing the simple joys and sorrows of childhood and her happy summer days.

The provided text, "Anna Karenina," unfolds the intertwined lives of several aristocratic Russian families, primarily focusing on the marital crises of Dolly Oblonskaya and Anna Karenina, and the spiritual journey of Konstantin Levin.

**Part One**

The narrative begins amidst the disarray of the Oblonskys' Moscow household. Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly), the wife, has discovered her husband, Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva), is having an affair with their French governess. Dolly declared she could no longer live with him, leading to three days of emotional turmoil affecting the entire household. Stiva wakes up in his study, plagued by guilt and the memory of Dolly's fury upon finding the incriminating letter. He laments his "idiotic smile" during the confrontation. He rationalizes his infidelity, believing Dolly, a "worn-out woman," should have been more indulgent. Matvey, Stiva's valet, informs him that his sister, Anna Arkadyevna, is arriving from Petersburg, suggesting she might mediate a reconciliation. Dolly, however, remains firm in her decision to leave, much to Stiva's dismay. The nurse, Matrona Philimonovna, urges Stiva to beg for forgiveness.

Stiva attends to his official duties and personal finances, finding an unpleasant issue with selling his wife's forest property. He also spends time with his children, Grisha and Tanya, noting Tanya's discomfort with the family's situation. He then decides to confront Dolly again. In her room, Dolly is packing but feels trapped by her love for Stiva and concern for her five children. Stiva's attempt to reconcile is met with Dolly's renewed rage, especially when he mentions his "instant of passion." She calls him "loathsome" and "repulsive," threatening to expose him publicly. A child's cry momentarily softens her, but she leaves the room, still resolute. Stiva is left feeling the "vulgarity" of the situation. Dolly, though still contemplating leaving, recognizes the impossibility of it and returns to her daily responsibilities.

Meanwhile, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, an old friend of Stiva's, arrives in Moscow. His true purpose is to propose to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister, whom he views as an idealized, perfect being. Levin feels unworthy due to his life as a country gentleman. He visits his half-brother, Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev, a philosopher, finding their intellectual discussions abstract and unfulfilling. Sergey Ivanovitch reveals their estranged elder brother, Nikolay, is in Moscow, and advises against seeing him. Levin, however, decides to visit Nikolay later. At the Zoological Gardens, Levin finds Kitty skating and is captivated by her. They skate together, holding hands, but Kitty's demeanor shifts, making Levin feel he has offended her. Kitty's mother invites Levin to their home. Levin leaves with Stiva, overjoyed yet uneasy.

At a restaurant, Oblonsky discusses Kitty with Levin, revealing Dolly's "foreseeing" belief that Kitty will marry Levin, which delights Levin. Levin confesses his past sins and feeling unworthy. Oblonsky mentions Count Vronsky as a rival for Kitty's affections, causing Levin anger and gloom. Oblonsky then confides in Levin about his own affair, defending his actions as part of life's "light and shadow." Levin, disgusted by Oblonsky's casual view of infidelity, resolves to propose to Kitty.

Kitty, caught between Levin and Vronsky, feels immense pressure. Her mother favors Vronsky, a wealthy and charming officer, over Levin. Kitty had refused Levin once, believing Vronsky had serious intentions. At the evening party, Levin proposes to Kitty, who, recalling Vronsky, hastily refuses him. Vronsky arrives, and Levin, witnessing Kitty's bright eyes when she looks at Vronsky, confirms his suspicions of her love. The old Prince Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's father, openly favors Levin but is cold to Vronsky. Levin leaves in despair.

Kitty tells her mother about Levin's proposal and her refusal, but is plagued by doubts and remorse for hurting him. Her parents argue, the Prince vehemently condemning the Princess for encouraging Vronsky, whom he suspects is merely flirting.

Vronsky, unaware of the family's turmoil, is exhilarated by his growing connection with Kitty. He sees marriage as "ridiculous" but feels a "secret spiritual bond" with Kitty. The next morning, at the Petersburg railway station, Vronsky meets Oblonsky, who is there to meet his sister, Anna Karenina. Oblonsky, unaware of Anna's confession to her husband, mentions Levin's rejected proposal to Kitty, implying Vronsky has a clear path. Vronsky feels like a "conqueror." A railway guard is crushed by a train; Anna, observing the accident, calls it an "omen of evil." Vronsky quietly donates money to the widow. Anna's initial meeting with Vronsky is marked by mutual fascination.

**Part Two**

Kitty's health declines, and doctors recommend a trip abroad to Soden. Her father blames the Princess for pushing Kitty toward Vronsky, causing Kitty immense shame and misery. Dolly visits, sharing her own marital woes, and reproaches Kitty for her outburst, but later understands her sister's suffering. Kitty confesses her deep unhappiness, her feeling that everything is "hateful, loathsome, coarse," and her "sham" attempts at charity work. She decides to stay with Dolly to help with her children, who have scarlet fever, before going abroad with her parents.

In Petersburg, Anna immerses herself in fashionable society, particularly with Princess Betsy Tverskaya. She realizes Vronsky's pursuit has become the "whole interest of her life." Vronsky, after mediating a scandal involving his friends, tells Betsy he is now fully "caught" by Anna. Anna confronts Vronsky about his past behavior toward Kitty, telling him to seek Kitty's forgiveness. Vronsky, in turn, passionately declares his love for Anna, stating she is his "whole life." Alexey Alexandrovitch enters Betsy's party and makes sarcastic remarks. Vronsky whispers to Anna that he will not change anything in their relationship for now. Anna later confesses to Alexey Alexandrovitch her love for Vronsky, feeling a sense of "shame, rapture, and horror" at this new life. She is haunted by a dream of both men being her husbands.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, deeply disturbed by Anna's confession, initially experiences relief, feeling like a "tooth had been pulled." He views Anna as "corrupt" and resolves to end their marriage while preserving his honor and punishing her. He considers dueling and divorce but rejects them for various reasons, including fear of scandal and the impact on Seryozha. He decides to keep Anna with him, demanding external propriety and the cessation of her affair, hoping for her "reformation." He formalizes this decision in a cold letter to Anna, enclosing money and ordering her return to Petersburg. Anna is horrified by his "base" generosity, interpreting it as a calculated move to control and torment her. She briefly considers running away with Seryozha but despairs, realizing her lack of strength to break from her old life. She sends a non-committal reply to her husband.

Vronsky, meanwhile, struggles with the implications of Anna's pregnancy, which complicates his established code of principles. He considers leaving the army but is pulled by ambition, inflamed by the success of his former rival, Serpuhovskoy. He is now consumed by "disgrace, humiliation, guilty" feelings towards Alexey Alexandrovitch's magnanimity. In a moment of despair, Vronsky attempts suicide with a revolver but only wounds himself. His brother's wife, Varya, nurses him. Alexey Alexandrovitch, transformed by his act of forgiveness during Anna's confinement, feels a profound spiritual peace and develops a tender attachment to Anna's newborn daughter, Annie. He sees his previous indifference to religion replaced by an ardent faith, guided by Countess Lidia Ivanovna. He is unaware of the social mockery he faces. Anna, still in Petersburg, is distressed by Vronsky's perceived coldness and the social ostracism she faces. Lidia Ivanovna actively prevents Anna from seeing Seryozha, believing Anna is a "bad woman" and that Alexey Alexandrovitch's new spiritual path must be protected.

Anna, desperate to see her son, attempts to visit him on his birthday, bribing servants to gain entry. She finds Seryozha, who recognizes and embraces her, despite his father's attempts to make him forget her. Seryozha expresses his love for her, but Anna, seeing the "dread and something like shame" in his face, realizes she must leave him. She tells him to love his father, who is "better and kinder." Alexey Alexandrovitch enters, and Anna, filled with "repulsion and hatred," quickly departs, leaving behind the toys she bought for Seryozha. Back at her hotel, Anna is consumed by despair, finding her love for her baby girl insufficient compared to her longing for Seryozha. She fears Vronsky's love is waning and confronts him. Their argument intensifies, with Anna accusing him of coldness and indifference. She speaks of her dream of dying in childbirth. Vronsky, horrified, reassures her of his love. He declines a prestigious appointment in Tashkend and retires from the army, committing to Anna. They leave for Italy without obtaining a divorce.

**Part Three**

Levin, now married to Kitty, is initially overwhelmed by the "pettiest details" of married life, which clashes with his idealized expectations. He and Kitty experience frequent quarrels, often stemming from misunderstanding and his jealousy. He is particularly vexed by her domestic preoccupations, but comes to admire her strength. After an argument where Kitty accuses him of not loving her, he realizes they are inextricably linked. Their honeymoon period is described as "bitterest and most humiliating."

They return to the country. Levin receives a letter from Marya Nikolaevna, his brother Nikolay's former mistress, stating Nikolay is dying and needs help. Kitty insists on accompanying Levin, causing another argument about her perceived weakness and his desire to travel alone. They reconcile, and both go to Nikolay's provincial hotel. Levin is horrified by Nikolay's emaciated appearance, but Kitty, with practical compassion, immediately takes charge, cleaning the room and caring for Nikolay. Levin is deeply moved by Kitty's unwavering love and strength. Nikolay dies after receiving extreme unction, murmuring "Right! ... O Lord!" Levin is overwhelmed by the mystery of death, but Kitty's presence and her pregnancy bring him back to life and love.

Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev visits Levin in the country, but Levin feels uncomfortable with his brother's detached, intellectual view of rural life and peasants. Levin is still struggling with his own farming methods and his inability to find meaning in public service. He is stung by Sergey Ivanovitch's criticisms of his indifference. During a day of mowing with the peasants, Levin finds profound satisfaction in physical labor and observes the simple, unquestioning faith of an old peasant, Fokanitch, who lives "for his soul, in truth, in God’s way." This sparks an epiphany in Levin: true meaning and goodness are intuitive and God-given, not discoverable by reason. He embraces faith, feeling a "spiritual peace" and "positive meaning of goodness" in his life, despite his lingering intellectual doubts and human flaws.

Levin is called home from the fields to meet Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov. Dolly tells him Vronsky is going to Servia. Levin and his guests debate the Servian War. Levin argues against private citizens engaging in war and murder, advocating for the "soul" over vengeance, but feels defeated by his brother's and Katavasov's intellectual arguments. A storm breaks, and Levin, fearing for Kitty and their son, Mitya, rushes to find them, relieved they are safe. He attends Mitya's bath, feeling a growing love for his child, though initially disappointed by his own paternal feelings. He sits on the terrace, reflecting on his intuitive faith, and resolves to keep it a personal secret.

**Part Four**

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's departure, is left alone with Seryozha in Petersburg. He is overcome by despair and humiliation, feeling abandoned and despised by society. Countess Lidia Ivanovna offers him moral and spiritual support, encouraging his new, mystical Christian faith. He finds solace in this "delusion of salvation," which allows him to dismiss his worldly troubles. Lidia Ivanovna, devoted to Alexey Alexandrovitch, intercepts a letter from Anna asking to see Seryozha, refusing Anna's request in a harsh letter. Seryozha, meanwhile, struggles with his father's new strict religious education and his mother's absence. He secretly searches for his mother, disbelieving she is wicked.

**Part Five**

Levin and Kitty are married. Levin, in a state of ecstatic happiness, is overwhelmed by the wedding preparations and his own confession of past impurity and unbelief to Kitty. Kitty, though pained by his confession of impurity, forgives him. They move to the country. Levin is initially disappointed by Kitty's domestic focus and their frequent quarrels, but he learns to appreciate her practical love. He is still wrestling with his new spiritual insights and the meaning of life, which he contrasts with the simple, unquestioning faith of the peasants. During his stay in Moscow, Levin again feels the pressure of social expectations and the emptiness of intellectual debates.

**Part Six**

Dolly and her children visit the Levins in the country. Kitty, now pregnant, thrives in her role as mistress of the house. Sergey Ivanovitch, having experienced the failure of his scholarly book, now dedicates himself to the "Slavonic question" (the Servian War), seeing it as a manifestation of the people's will. During a mushroom-picking excursion, Sergey Ivanovitch almost proposes to Varenka, but hesitates, unable to overcome his loyalty to his deceased love. Kitty is disappointed by this missed opportunity.

Stepan Arkadyevitch arrives with Vassenka Veslovsky, a charming but flirtatious young man. Levin becomes intensely jealous of Veslovsky's attention to Kitty. In a fit of rage, Levin confronts Kitty, accusing her of encouraging Veslovsky. Kitty, though initially offended, is touched by his deep love and reassures him. Levin, still furious, orders Veslovsky to leave. Stepan Arkadyevitch is dismayed by Levin's "ridiculous" jealousy, but Levin remains firm. Dolly visits Anna in the country, experiencing the luxury and cultivated atmosphere of her new life with Vronsky. Dolly is conflicted; she admires Anna's happiness but feels uncomfortable with the moral implications of her situation. Anna confesses her anxieties about Vronsky's waning love and her desperate desire for a divorce to legitimize their relationship and their daughter, Annie. She also reveals her inability to have more children. Dolly, though sympathetic, is horrified by these revelations.

**Part Seven**

Levin and Kitty are in Moscow, awaiting Kitty's overdue confinement. Levin feels restless and out of place in the city, missing his purposeful country life. He has money troubles. He meets Kitty's sister, Natalia, and her husband, Lvov, who discusses the challenges of raising children and the importance of religion. Levin is impressed by Lvov's sincerity. He attends a concert, finding the new music confusing, and makes an awkward social call. At the club, Levin is reconciled with Vronsky, finding a surprising ease in his company. Stepan Arkadyevitch urges Levin to visit Anna, who is in Moscow awaiting her divorce. Levin visits Anna, who captivates him with her intelligence and charm. Anna confides in Levin about her difficult position and her struggle for a divorce. Levin, though still judging her, feels tenderness and pity.

Kitty becomes jealous of Levin's visit to Anna, accusing him of loving Anna. Levin soothes her by confessing his pity for Anna and his own struggles with Moscow life. Anna, meanwhile, is plagued by Vronsky's perceived coldness and his continued delays in arranging a divorce. She confronts him, leading to a bitter argument. She suggests her impending death as a release. Vronsky, horrified, reassures her of his love and agrees to leave Moscow with her.

Kitty's labor begins, filling Levin with terror. He prays desperately for her safety, experiencing a profound spiritual awakening. After an agonizing twenty-two hours, Kitty gives birth to a healthy boy, Mitya. Levin is overcome with joy, realizing his love and faith have saved him from despair. He still struggles with the abstractness of his new faith, but accepts it as an intuitive, inexpressible truth.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, facing financial ruin, goes to Petersburg to secure a new, lucrative government post and to press Alexey Alexandrovitch for Anna's divorce. He meets with Alexey Alexandrovitch, who, under the influence of Countess Lidia Ivanovna and the clairvoyant Landau, refuses the divorce, citing Christian principles and his responsibility to Seryozha. Seryozha, meanwhile, continues to struggle with his separation from his mother, repressing his memories of her.

Anna, after her son's birthday visit, is increasingly desperate. She feels Vronsky's love waning, and her jealousy intensifies. After a bitter quarrel, she believes Vronsky hates her and loves another. She contemplates suicide as a way to punish him and regain his love. After sending a desperate note to Vronsky, who is away, she travels to the railway station. Overwhelmed by despair and remembering the man crushed by a train, she throws herself under the wheels, dying instantly.

**Part Eight**

Sergey Ivanovitch's scholarly book is a failure. He channels his energy into the Servian War, seeing it as a great national cause. He and Katavasov travel to the country, encountering volunteers for the war. Countess Vronskaya, seeing Vronsky off to Servia, blames Anna for ruining her son and describes Vronsky's despair and suicide attempt after Anna's death. She sees the war as a "providential blessing" for him. Vronsky, looking "aged and worn by suffering," confesses to Sergey Ivanovitch that life is "worth nothing" to him and he is glad to have a cause to die for. He is haunted by the memory of Anna's body at the station.

Levin, at home, is told about Vronsky's departure. He debates the war with Sergey Ivanovitch and the old prince, arguing against private involvement in murder. He maintains that true good comes from living "for one's soul," not from abstract political causes. He feels defeated in argument but remains firm in his intuitive faith. A storm brings a moment of fear for Kitty and Mitya, reinforcing Levin's focus on love and family. He reflects on his newfound faith, concluding that while he will continue to struggle with life's imperfections, his spiritual strength is "untouched," and his life now holds a "positive meaning of goodness." He embraces this personal, inexpressible faith, understanding that it provides the ultimate answer to life's meaning.

Raskolnikov, a handsome but impoverished former student, lives in a cramped garret in S. Place, deeply in debt to his landlady. He avoids her due to his debts and his own irritable, hypochondriac state, which has led him to isolate himself. He harbors a secret plan, which he initially dismisses as a fantasy, but now, a month later, views as an impending "exploit."

On a hot July evening, Raskolnikov sets out for a "rehearsal" of his plan. He walks to a large house, carefully avoiding detection, and ascends to the fourth floor where an old pawnbroker, Alyona Ivanovna, lives. He notes that a German clerk is moving out of the adjoining flat, leaving the old woman alone. He rings her bell. Alyona, a sixty-year-old, withered woman with suspicious eyes, opens the door cautiously. Raskolnikov, introducing himself as a former client, presents an old silver watch to pawn. Alyona reminds him that his previous pledge is overdue and offers a meager sum for the watch. Raskolnikov, angered but having "another object" in mind, takes the money. He then tries to ascertain if Alyona's sister, Lizaveta, is always home with her. As he leaves, he feels intense repulsion for the "atrocious thing" he contemplates. He stops at a tavern, drinks beer, and feels his thoughts clear.

In the tavern, he encounters a drunken former government clerk, Marmeladov, who engages him in a rambling monologue. Marmeladov describes his crushing poverty and the shame of his beggary, contrasting it with his proud, educated wife, Katerina Ivanovna, an officer's daughter. He confesses to selling his wife’s belongings for drink, leaving her and their three small children in destitution, and how his daughter from his first marriage, Sonia, has been forced into prostitution ("yellow ticket") to support the family. He recounts a poignant scene where Sonia silently placed her earnings on the table, and Katerina Ivanovna knelt and kissed her feet. Marmeladov then admits to stealing his remaining earnings five days prior and spending them on drink, leaving his family to starve. He confesses he obtained the drink he is currently consuming from Sonia, who gave him her last thirty copecks. Marmeladov, in despair, declares he should be crucified, not pitied, and speaks of God's eventual forgiveness for Sonia. He asks Raskolnikov to accompany him home.

They arrive at Katerina Ivanovna’s squalid room. Katerina Ivanovna, emaciated and coughing blood, is enraged to find Marmeladov drunk and without money. She drags him by his hair, while he calls it "consolation." The children are terrified. Katerina Ivanovna turns on Raskolnikov, accusing him of drinking with her husband. As Raskolnikov leaves, he places a small amount of money (coppers) on the window unnoticed. He debates taking it back, then dismisses it. He reflects on the "vileness" of man and his own dark thoughts.

The next morning, Raskolnikov wakes from a troubled sleep in his dilapidated room. Nastasya, his landlady’s servant, informs him that his landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, plans to report him to the police for unpaid rent. He also receives a letter from his mother. The letter details his sister Dounia's recent ordeal as a governess, where her employer, Mr. Svidrigaïlov, made indecent proposals. Dounia was unjustly accused and humiliated by Svidrigaïlov's wife, Marfa Petrovna, but was later publicly vindicated when Svidrigaïlov provided proof of her innocence. The letter also announces Dounia's engagement to Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a wealthy, forty-five-year-old counsellor, who, despite some rude remarks about marrying a poor woman to be her benefactor, is seen as a means to secure Raskolnikov's future and enable him to finish his studies. His mother and Dounia are coming to Petersburg soon.

Raskolnikov, enraged by the letter, views the marriage as a sacrifice for his sake and vows it "shall not be." He feels both pity and hatred for his family. He despises Luzhin. He then has a vivid dream of his childhood, witnessing a drunken peasant, Mikolka, brutally beating a weak old mare to death. He wakes in terror, realizing the dream mirrors his own murderous impulses. He again dismisses his dark plan as "base, loathsome, vile." However, later in the Hay Market, he overhears Lizaveta, the pawnbroker's sister, arranging to be away from home the next day at seven o'clock, leaving Alyona Ivanovna alone. This information, a "predestined turning-point," solidifies his resolve. He remembers an earlier tavern conversation where a student casually discussed the idea of killing the "useless" old pawnbroker for the greater good.

On the day of the murder, Raskolnikov, in a feverish state, prepares a fake "pledge" (a piece of wood with metal) and a noose to conceal an axe. He creeps downstairs to steal an axe from his landlady's kitchen but finds Nastasya there. Crushed, he almost gives up but then spots an axe in the porter's open room, takes it, and conceals it. He reaches Alyona Ivanovna's flat around seven. He rings the bell, his heart pounding. Alyona, suspicious, opens the door slightly. Raskolnikov pushes his way in and, as she examines the fake pledge with her back to him, strikes her head repeatedly with the blunt side of the axe, killing her. He takes her keys and finds a large strong-box under her bed, filled with gold and jewels. As he is stuffing his pockets, Lizaveta unexpectedly enters. Frozen in terror, she does not scream. Raskolnikov, in a panic, strikes her with the sharp edge of the axe, killing her instantly.

Overwhelmed by fear and loathing, he washes his hands and the axe in the kitchen. He is shocked to find the main door to the staircase wide open. He hears footsteps approaching and slips into an empty flat on the second floor where painters had been working. The approaching men (Koch and a student) stop at the old woman's door, realizing it is only hooked from the inside, meaning someone is home. They go to fetch the porter. Raskolnikov slips out and escapes. Disoriented, he hides the stolen items under a stone in a deserted courtyard. He feels a momentary triumph, then a terrible sickness and repulsion.

He then receives a police summons for an unpaid IOU. At the police station, he faints, but is relieved to find the summons is only for debt, not the murder. While there, he overhears police discussing the murder of Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta. He realizes they suspect the painter, Nikolay, who had tried to hang himself and confessed. Raskolnikov, in his delirium, admits to Razumihin that he has been thinking about the murder and speaks of hidden jewelry. Razumihin purchases new clothes for Raskolnikov with money sent by his mother, and tears up the IOU.

Svidrigaïlov, Dounia's former employer, visits Raskolnikov, revealing he knows Raskolnikov's secret and that Marfa Petrovna left Dounia three thousand roubles in her will. He states he has come to Petersburg to see Dounia and offers her ten thousand roubles to break off her engagement to Luzhin, claiming his passion for her has passed. He makes it clear that he will use Raskolnikov's secret against Dounia if Raskolnikov doesn't cooperate. Raskolnikov is enraged and threatens to kill him.

Meanwhile, Luzhin, still smarting from the broken engagement, makes a false accusation against Sonia at Marmeladov's memorial dinner, claiming she stole a hundred-rouble note from him. Lebeziatnikov, who witnessed Luzhin plant the money in Sonia's pocket, exposes Luzhin's scheme. Raskolnikov then reveals Luzhin's malicious motives: to discredit him and regain Dounia's favor. Luzhin is forced to leave. Katerina Ivanovna, in a fit of despair and madness, is evicted by the landlady and runs into the street with her children to beg. She collapses, bleeding from consumption, and is taken to Sonia's room, where she dies in Sonia's arms. Svidrigaïlov, who had been listening from the adjoining room, offers to take care of the Marmeladov children and give Sonia three thousand roubles.

Raskolnikov is deeply troubled. Dounia visits him, expressing love and offering support, but he pushes her away, saying he must be alone. He then goes to Sonia, confessing he killed Alyona Ivanovna and Lizaveta. He reveals he did it for power, to test his theory of being an "extraordinary man," not for money, which he hid under a stone. Sonia, distraught, urges him to confess publicly, embrace suffering, and find redemption. He resists, still clinging to his pride and denying it was a "crime" but rather a "blunder."

Svidrigaïlov, after visiting his own young betrothed and giving her money, commits suicide with a revolver.

Raskolnikov, deeply shaken, finally accepts Sonia's plea. He goes to the Hay Market, kneels down, and kisses the earth, although the full confession of "I am a murderer" dies on his lips due to the mocking crowd. He sees Sonia watching him from afar. He then proceeds to the police station, where he encounters the "Explosive Lieutenant," Ilya Petrovitch. He hears of Svidrigaïlov's suicide. With Sonia waiting outside, Raskolnikov, pale and trembling, confesses to Ilya Petrovitch that he "killed the old pawnbroker woman and her sister Lizaveta with an axe and robbed them."

In Siberia, Raskolnikov is sentenced to eight years of penal servitude. He confesses completely at his trial, explaining every detail, including the hidden items. The court, noting his refusal to use the stolen money and his hypochondriacal state, concludes he acted under "temporary mental derangement." Despite this, Raskolnikov maintains his crime was a "blunder," not morally wrong, as his conscience is "at rest." He struggles with his wounded pride and the "impossible gulf" between himself and other convicts. He is reviled by his fellow prisoners as an "infidel." Sonia follows him to Siberia, visiting him regularly. Initially, Raskolnikov is sullen and distant, but gradually, through Sonia's unwavering love and his own suffering, he begins a "gradual renewal" and "regeneration" into a new life. He realizes he loves Sonia, and their shared suffering opens a path to a new, unknown future. The story ends with him picking up Sonia's New Testament, filled with the dawn of a new life, though the process of his full spiritual transformation is just beginning.

The story begins in Munich on a spring afternoon in 19--, with Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer, or von Aschenbach as he was officially known after his fiftieth birthday. Overworked and unable to rest after a demanding forenoon, he takes a long walk. As he waits for a tram at the North Cemetery, he notices a man with an unusual, somewhat pug-nosed, red-haired, and bold appearance. This encounter stirs in Aschenbach a powerful, long-dormant desire for travel, a "youthful longing after far-off places," which he visualizes as a tropical, primeval swampland. He realizes this yearning is an urge to escape his rigorous work, which, despite his mastery, has become stalled and lacks emotional fire. He decides to take a short, restful trip to a pleasant resort in the South.

The narrative then delves into Aschenbach's background. He is the son of a high-ranking official, with ancestors known for their severe, steady lives, though his mother brought a more sensuous Bohemian influence. Aschenbach, always driven to build a reputation, achieved fame early through disciplined and painstaking effort, despite a frail constitution and a lack of carefree youth. He believed in "carrying through" and creating art that matured with age. His literary works, like the epic on Frederick of Prussia and the novel "Maya," were meticulously crafted. He was celebrated for creating a new hero-type: an "intellectual and youthful masculinity" that maintained self-mastery against adversity. He had once renounced youthful skepticism and irony, embracing dignity and rejecting knowledge that might weaken the will, as seen in his story "The Wretch." His later style became more formal and conservative, earning him official recognition, including nobility on his fiftieth birthday. He settled in Munich, a widower with a married daughter. His face, though outwardly calm, bore the marks of his intense artistic life.

About two weeks after his walk, in mid-to-late May, Aschenbach departs. He travels by night train to Trieste, then by ship to an Adriatic island. However, the island's cold, damp weather, provincial clientele, and lack of a sandy beach dissatisfy him. He abruptly realizes his true destination is Venice. He leaves the island, taking a motorboat to a naval port and then boarding a decrepit Italian steamer bound for Venice. On board, he is disturbed by a man he initially perceives as a youth, but soon realizes is an old fop in disguise, wearing makeup, a wig, and false teeth, yet accepted by his younger companions. Aschenbach feels a "dream-like estrangement."

Upon arriving in the Venetian lagoon, the ship waits for a health department boat. During this wait, the old fop, now painfully drunk, makes lewd and offensive gestures. Aschenbach, repulsed, feels the world distorting. When the ship finally reaches San Marco, Aschenbach arranges for a gondola to take him to the Lido, intending to use a steamer. The drunken fop accosts him again with a strange, slurred farewell. Aschenbach boards a black gondola, which reminds him of a coffin and death. He is surprised when the gondolier, a brutal-looking, non-Italian man, heads for the open sea instead of the steamer dock. The gondolier insists Aschenbach is going directly to the Lido and dismisses his request for the steamer, claiming it won't take luggage. Aschenbach, feeling strangely inert and wondering if the man is a criminal, gives in. After paying money to a boatload of musical brigands who sing alongside, they reach the Lido. Aschenbach goes to get change for the gondolier at a hotel, only to find on his return that the gondola and gondolier have vanished. An old man on the dock informs him the gondolier was unlicensed and that Aschenbach had ridden for free.

Aschenbach proceeds to the beach hotel, where he is welcomed by the manager and shown to a pleasant room with a sea view. Still disturbed by the strange incidents, he observes the hotel guests. He is captivated by a Polish family, particularly a fourteen-year-old boy of extraordinary beauty, who reminds him of Greek sculpture. The boy, dressed luxuriously, stands in stark contrast to his chastely dressed sisters. Aschenbach watches the boy's polite interaction with his mother, a richly jeweled woman, and feels a peculiar touch.

The next day, the dreary weather and the persistent smell of the lagoon depress Aschenbach. He considers leaving again, fearing a return of old ailments. At breakfast, he sees the Polish girls and their governess, but not the boy. The boy, Tadzio, eventually appears, his graceful movements and "godlike beauty" astonishing Aschenbach. He wears a striking blue and white striped blouse. Aschenbach, delighted, feels he wants to stay as long as Tadzio does. On the beach, Aschenbach enjoys the scene, reflecting on his love for the ocean. He watches Tadzio, who, wading barefoot, displays a moment of scorn and detestation towards a Russian family. Aschenbach is both cheered and unsettled by this "childish fanaticism." He deciphers the boy's name as "Tadzio." He observes Tadzio playing with other children, including a boy named Jaschu, who kisses him. Aschenbach watches Tadzio emerge from the sea, a "frail god," sparking a "sense of myth" in him. He feels a "paternal affection" for the boy.

Later, in the lift, Aschenbach sees Tadzio close up and notices his teeth are "jagged and pale," suggesting he is "frail, sickly," and "will not grow old." Aschenbach feels a peculiar "gratification" at this thought. That afternoon, Aschenbach visits Venice, but the oppressive sultriness, mixed odors, and crowds make him feel ill. He decides to leave the city, finding it unhealthy for him. He returns to his hotel, announces his departure for the next morning, and packs. The next morning, he regrets his hasty decision but feels compelled to follow through. As he finishes breakfast, Tadzio enters the buffet room, and their eyes meet. Aschenbach silently bids him farewell.

On the steamboat leaving Venice, Aschenbach is overcome with misery and spiritual hunger, realizing his deep attachment to the city and regretting his departure. He believes he can never return, as Venice twice affected his health. At the station, in an intense internal conflict, he discovers his large trunk was mistakenly sent to Como. Instead of being distressed, Aschenbach feels an "adventurous delight" and "unbelievable hilarity." He declares he won't travel without his trunk and decides to return to the Lido to wait for it. He manages to redeem his ticket and within twenty minutes is on a motorboat heading back to the Lido. He laughs at this "comically dreamlike mishap," seeing it as fate driving him back, allowing him to rectify a grave error. He is met by the manager and given an almost identical room. Relaxing, he sees Tadzio returning from the sea. Aschenbach feels "exhilaration," realizing Tadzio was the reason his departure was so difficult. He makes a "spontaneous act of welcome, of calm acceptance."

Days pass in sunny, idle comfort. Aschenbach remains at the Lido, fully unpacked. He frequently sees Tadzio on the beach, observing his movements, his beauty, and his interactions with his companions. He is constantly astonished by Tadzio's delicate appeal, feeling he is witnessing "the beautiful itself, form as the thought of God." He is inspired by this "drunkenness" and, recalling Plato's Phaedrus, feels an irresistible desire to write. He works on a prose tract in Tadzio's presence, using the boy's "godlike" form as his aesthetic standard. After these efforts, he feels exhausted and his conscience "complaining after some transgression."

One morning, he attempts to approach Tadzio on the beach to strike up a friendly acquaintance but is overcome by a pounding heart and shortness of breath, forcing him to pass by with bowed head. He realizes he doesn't want "soberness"; his "intoxication was too precious." He dismisses self-criticism and jokes about his "comically pious distress." He extends his stay, sending for more money, his only concern now Tadzio's possible departure. He spends his days basking in the sun and sea air, feeling a renewed sense of elation and emotion. His sleep is fitful, and he wakes at dawn to watch the sunrise, imagining Eros rising and Tadzio as Hyacinth, a beautiful youth loved by gods and destined to die. He observes Tadzio's subtle gestures, noticing that the boy now passes closer to his spot on the beach.

One evening, Tadzio, returning from the city with his family, meets Aschenbach's gaze and smiles "eloquently, familiarly, charmingly, without concealment"—a "smile of Narcissus." Overwhelmed, Aschenbach flees to the dark park, whispering, "I love you!"

In his fourth week at the Lido, Aschenbach notices fewer guests, especially Germans. He overhears the barber mention "the plague." Later, in Venice, he detects a sweet, drug-like smell of sickness and sees official posters warning against gastric diseases, euphemistically covering up a deeper issue. A shop proprietor evasively dismisses his questions. Back at the hotel, Aschenbach finds censored newspapers, confirming a cover-up. He feels a "dark contentment" that the world's disorder conspires with his own secret passion, fearing Tadzio's departure more than the plague.

He now stalks Tadzio, following him covertly through Venice's labyrinthine streets and canals. He even takes a gondola to pursue Tadzio's. He finds himself caught in a decadent enchantment, recalling that Venice is a diseased city concealing its condition. He returns late one evening, pressing his head against Tadzio's room door, overwhelmed by his infatuation. He has moments of self-reproach, recalling his ancestors' rigid principles and reflecting on how his life, devoted to art and passion, has become "degenerate," leading him down a "perilous road." He learns the truth about the spreading Indian cholera from an English clerk: the disease has taken hold in Venice, with high fatality rates, and authorities are suppressing the information for economic reasons, leading to demoralization and increased crime. The clerk advises him to leave immediately before a quarantine.

Aschenbach, though horrified, feels a "feverish excitement" and "triumph" in possessing this secret. He considers warning Tadzio's mother but realizes he doesn't truly want to. He whispers, "It must be kept silent!" and "I will keep silent!" His complicity intoxicates him, and he chooses to stay. That night, he experiences a "frightful dream" of a Dionysian orgy, a violent, lewd bacchanalian ritual where he is overwhelmed and embraces the "unchastity and fury of decay."

He wakes shattered, no longer caring about being noticed. Guests are fleeing, but Tadzio's family remains. Aschenbach feels that flight and death might remove all distractions, leaving him alone with the boy. He tries to please Tadzio, rejuvenating his appearance with youthful clothes, jewels, and perfumes. He frequently visits the barber, who dyes his hair black, curls it, touches up his eyes, adds crimson to his cheeks, and smooths his wrinkles, making him look young again. The barber tells him, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly." Aschenbach, transformed, feels "happy as in a dream."

One afternoon, he tracks Tadzio deep into the diseased city, becoming lost. Tadzio, lagging behind his family, repeatedly turns to glance back at Aschenbach, acknowledging his presence but not betraying him. Aschenbach, "drunk with the knowledge of this," follows until he loses sight of Tadzio after a bridge. Exhausted and parched, he buys and eats overly ripe strawberries. He sits by a cistern in a quiet square, reflecting on his fall from dignity and the perilous road of the artist, which leads to "intoxication and to desire," and ultimately to "the precipice." He concludes his internal monologue by saying, "I am going, Phaedrus. You stay here; and when you no longer see me, then you go too."

A few days later, feeling unwell with vertigo and malaise, Aschenbach learns that the Polish family is leaving after lunch. He nods and goes to the beach, which now has an "air of autumn" and is almost abandoned. Tadzio is playing a degenerating game with his remaining companions. Jaschu, in a wrestling match, pins Tadzio and nearly strangles him in the sand. Aschenbach, enraged, is about to intervene when Jaschu releases him. Tadzio, pale and upset, walks slowly away, ignoring his companions, and goes to the water's edge. He wades out to a sand-bank, stands facing the open sea, then slowly walks along the narrow stretch of ground. He stops, turns in a beautiful twist, and looks back towards the shore. His gaze meets Aschenbach's. Aschenbach's head sinks to his breast, his face taking on the "relaxed expression of deep sleep." It seems to him that Tadzio is smiling and nodding, signaling him to come out, guiding him towards "egregious promises." Aschenbach stands up to follow him.

Minutes later, Aschenbach collapses in his chair. He is brought to his room, and "on the same day a respectfully shocked world received the news of his death."
