Aunt Polly recognized Tom and Huck, exposing their identities to the Phelpses. Aunt Polly confirmed Miss Watson's will.

In the end, Jim was freed and treated well by the Phelps family for his help. Tom gave Jim forty dollars for his patient "imprisonment," fulfilling Jim's prediction of becoming rich. Tom then proposed new adventures among the "Injuns." Huck, thinking he had no money (assuming Pap took it), was told by Tom that his six thousand dollars was still safe with Judge Thatcher, as Pap had never returned. Jim then solemnly revealed that the dead man in the floating house they had seen earlier was Pap, confirming Huck's earliest suspicion. Tom, nearly recovered, wore the bullet from his leg on a watch-guard. Huck, weary of the process of writing a book and facing adoption and "sivilization" by Aunt Sally, declared he would "light out for the territory ahead of the rest."

book_title: The Count of Monte Cristo-Alexandre Dumas
summary_llm:
On the 24th of February, 1815, the three-master *Pharaon* arrives in Marseilles. Edmond Dantès, the young and capable first mate, reports the death of Captain Leclere and is praised by the shipowner, M. Morrel, who promises him the captaincy. This news elates Edmond, who is engaged to the beautiful Catalan girl, Mercédès. However, it also stirs fierce jealousy in Danglars, the supercargo, and Fernand Mondego, Mercédès' cousin who is also in love with her.

Edmond first visits his father, finding him in poverty, having paid a debt to Caderousse. Edmond gives his father his savings and promises a better life. He then goes to Mercédès, who rejects Fernand's advances, affirming her love for Edmond. Fernand is left seething with hatred. Danglars and Fernand conspire at a tavern, fabricating an anonymous letter denouncing Edmond as a Bonapartist agent carrying secret letters from Napoleon at Elba to a committee in Paris. Fernand posts the letter, while Caderousse, drunk, is vaguely aware of the plot.

At Edmond and Mercédès' wedding feast, Edmond is dramatically arrested by a magistrate and soldiers. Edmond is taken to M. de Villefort, the Deputy Procureur du Roi. Edmond truthfully recounts his voyage, including his stop at the Island of Elba to deliver a packet for Marshal Bertrand, where he briefly encountered Napoleon. Upon reading the anonymous letter, Villefort is horrified to discover it is addressed to his own father, M. Noirtier, a prominent Bonapartist. To protect his own royalist reputation and impending marriage into an aristocratic family, Villefort burns the letter—the only proof against Edmond—and condemns Edmond to indefinite imprisonment in the Château d'If, dismissing M. Morrel's pleas for mercy.

Edmond endures years of solitary confinement, battling despair and even attempting suicide by starvation. After four years, he hears a scratching sound and discovers another prisoner, the Abbé Faria, who has been digging an escape tunnel. They become close friends, and Faria educates Edmond extensively in various languages, sciences, history, and philosophy, transforming him into a highly intelligent and cultured man. Faria also reveals the location and details of the immense Spada family treasure on the deserted island of Monte Cristo, discovered from a partially burned will, making Edmond memorize the details.

Faria suffers three catalepsy attacks. During the third, fatal attack, Edmond switches places with Faria's corpse in the burial sack. He is thrown into the sea, weighted by a cannonball, but cuts himself free with a knife (made by Faria) and swims to the island of Tiboulen. He is rescued by a smuggling ship, *La Jeune Amélie*, and works with the crew, learning their trade. He transforms his appearance, cutting his hair and beard, becoming unrecognizable.

Edmond, now a rich and powerful figure known as the Count of Monte Cristo, begins to implement his elaborate plan of reward and retribution. He first returns to Marseilles, discovers his father died of starvation and Mercédès has disappeared. Disguised as the Abbé Busoni, he visits Caderousse, who is now a poor innkeeper. Caderousse, believing he is confessing, reveals the full extent of Danglars and Fernand's roles in Edmond's betrayal and his father's death. Monte Cristo gives Caderousse a diamond, explaining it was Edmond's legacy, but Caderousse's greed leads him to murder a jeweler (Joannes) for it, and he is eventually caught and sentenced to the galleys.

Monte Cristo, disguised as a clerk, also visits M. Morrel, who is facing imminent bankruptcy. Morrel's last ship, the *Pharaon*, is overdue. Monte Cristo extends his debts and later orchestrates the miraculous arrival of a new ship, identical to the *Pharaon*, saving Morrel from ruin and restoring his family's fortune. He also sends a diamond for Morrel's daughter, Julie, as a dowry.

Years later, in Paris, Monte Cristo has established himself as a prominent and mysterious figure. He introduces Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti and his supposed son, Andrea Cavalcanti (who is actually Benedetto, the escaped galley-slave and Caderousse's former accomplice), into Parisian society as wealthy Italian noblemen, using them as pawns in his scheme against Danglars.

Fernand Mondego, now the Count of Morcerf, a decorated general and peer of France, is exposed in the House of Peers by Haydée, Monte Cristo's Greek slave and adopted daughter. Haydée testifies that Fernand betrayed her father, Ali Tepelini, Pasha of Yanina, to the Turks, receiving money in exchange for his family. This public accusation, based on documents provided by Monte Cristo, completely disgraces Fernand, leading to his ruin and later suicide.

In the Villefort household, tragedy strikes. Madame de Villefort, driven by avarice, systematically poisons her husband's first in-laws, the Saint-Mérans, and the loyal servant, Barrois, to secure Valentine's inheritance for her son, Edward. Dr. d'Avrigny, the family physician, suspects poisoning but is reluctant to accuse. However, M. Noirtier, Valentine's paralyzed grandfather, having built an immunity to brucine (which d'Avrigny administered for his condition), secretly protects Valentine by giving her small, increasing doses of the same poison, making her resistant.

Maximilian Morrel, who secretly loves Valentine, discovers her supposed death and attempts to take his own life. Monte Cristo intervenes, revealing his true identity as Edmond Dantès and the entire conspiracy. He explains he had been watching over Valentine and exchanged her poisoned draughts for an antidote, causing her to appear dead but actually placing her in a cataleptic state.

Benedetto (Andrea Cavalcanti) is arrested for Caderousse's murder. At his trial, he publicly reveals that M. de Villefort is his father, describing the circumstances of his birth and abandonment. Villefort, overwhelmed by this devastating exposure of his past crime, descends into madness. He rushes home to find his wife, Héloïse, and their son, Edward, dead, having committed suicide by poison. Villefort, clutching the body of his child, begins digging frantically in the garden, searching for the child he buried alive years ago.

Albert de Morcerf, witnessing his father's public disgrace and suicide, confronts Monte Cristo. Mercédès, who had recognized Edmond earlier, pleads with him to spare Albert. Edmond, moved by her anguish, reveals his identity and the full truth to Albert. Albert, rejecting his father's tainted name and fortune, apologizes to Monte Cristo, takes his mother, and leaves for Africa to start a new life, having accepted a small sum from Edmond—the same money Edmond buried in their old Marseilles garden. Mercédès chooses a life of humble seclusion.

Danglars, having fled Paris with his remaining millions, is captured by Luigi Vampa's bandits in Italy. Vampa, acting on Monte Cristo's orders, starves Danglars and forces him to pay exorbitant sums for food, gradually depleting his fortune. Finally, Monte Cristo reveals himself to the broken and penniless Danglars as Edmond Dantès, reminding him of his past cruelties. He leaves Danglars with 50,000 francs, revealing that the millions Danglars stole from the hospitals have been recovered.

Monte Cristo reunites Maximilian and a recovered Valentine on the Island of Monte Cristo. He gives them the Spada treasure as a wedding gift, and urges them to live happily, reminding Maximilian that true wisdom is found in "Wait and hope." Haydée, who has remained devoted to Monte Cristo, confesses her love, which he accepts. Monte Cristo and Haydée depart on his yacht, leaving the reunited lovers to their new life.

The Decameron begins with a Proem where the author, Giovanni Boccaccio, reflects on a past "high and noble passion" that caused him great suffering, from which he found solace in the discourse of a friend. Now free from its bonds, he desires to offer similar comfort to ladies who, being more constrained and unable to distract themselves from lovesickness or melancholy, are in greater need of solace than men. He proposes to achieve this by recounting one hundred stories, told over ten days, by a company of seven ladies and three young men. These tales will offer delightful and useful lessons on various love-chances and accidents of fortune.

**Day the First**
The narrative proper opens with a description of the devastating plague that afflicted Florence in 1348. The plague, characterized by plague-boils and black blotches, killed rapidly and was highly contagious, spreading through contact with the sick or their belongings. Society broke down: laws dissolved, families abandoned their sick, and traditional burial rites were replaced by mass graves. People adopted various behaviors, from strict seclusion to unrestrained revelry, all trying to escape or cope with the omnipresent death. The author estimates over a hundred thousand perished in Florence.

Amidst this calamity, seven young ladies – Pampinea, Fiammetta, Filomena, Emilia, Lauretta, Neifile, and Elisa – gather in the venerable church of Santa Maria Novella. Pampinea proposes they retreat to a country estate to escape the horrors and live agreeably. Filomena, while agreeing, wisely suggests that a company of women alone would be disorderly and susceptible to scandal, and that they need the guidance of men. Three young men – Pamfilo, Filostrato, and Dioneo – who are also seeking solace and whose mistresses are among the ladies, enter the church. Pampinea, related to one of them, invites them to join, promising a "pure and brotherly spirit." The young men joyfully accept.

The next morning, the company, with their servants, leaves Florence for a beautiful palace on a hill. Dioneo, the merriest, insists they live merrily, having left their cares in the city. Pampinea, elected the first queen, establishes rules: a new chief will be chosen daily to maintain order, and the household duties are assigned to the servants. After enjoying the gardens, they dine and entertain themselves with music and dancing. In the afternoon, the queen proposes storytelling as a pleasant way to pass the hot hours. All agree, and Pampinea decrees that for the first day, each may tell any story they like. Pamfilo is asked to begin.

**Pamfilo's Story (First Day, First Story): Master Ciappelletto**
Pamfilo recounts the tale of Master Ciappelletto da Prato, an infamously wicked scrivener known for forgery, false witness, violence, and blasphemy. He is hired by Musciatto Franzesi, a Florentine merchant, to deal with litigious Burgundian debtors. Ciappelletto falls ill at the house of two Florentine usurers. The brothers fear that if he dies unconfessed, his body will be disgraced, leading to public unrest against them. Ciappelletto, overhearing their fears, resolves to resolve the situation by committing one last, great deception. He requests a holy friar for confession. In a masterful performance, Ciappelletto invents a life of extreme piety, virginity, charity, and righteous anger, confessing only minor "sins" like drinking water too eagerly or cursing his mother as a child (for which he weeps profusely). The friar, completely deceived, believes him a saint. Ciappelletto dies. The friar proclaims his sanctity, and he is buried with great honor, becoming "Saint Ciappelletto," to whom miracles are attributed. Pamfilo concludes that God, in His benignity, hears the prayers of the faithful, regardless of the intercessor's true character.

**Neifile's Story (First Day, Second Story): Abraham the Jew**
Neifile tells of Jehannot de Chevigné, a devout Parisian merchant, who tries to convert his Jewish friend, Abraham, to Christianity. Abraham agrees to consider it, but only after visiting Rome to observe the Pope and clergy. Jehannot is distraught, fearing the notorious corruption of the Roman court will deter Abraham. However, upon returning from Rome, Abraham declares his intention to convert. He explains that, despite witnessing extreme lust, avarice, and gluttony among the clergy, he concludes that a religion that not only survives but flourishes under such leadership must truly be sustained by the Holy Spirit. He is baptized Giovanni and lives a devout life.

**Filomena's Story (First Day, Third Story): Melchizedek the Jew**
Filomena relates how Saladin, the Soldan of Babylon, in urgent need of money, plots to extort it from the rich but miserly Jew, Melchizedek. Saladin asks Melchizedek which of the three religions (Jewish, Saracen, or Christian) is the true one, hoping to trap him. Melchizedek, perceiving the snare, replies with the story of a father who had a precious ring to designate his heir. Having three equally beloved sons, he secretly had two identical rings made and gave one to each. Upon his death, all three sons produced their rings, but the true one could not be distinguished, so the question of the true heir remained pending. Melchizedek concludes that similarly, each religion believes itself to have the true law, but the question remains undecided. Saladin, impressed by his wisdom, reveals his financial need. Melchizedek freely lends him the money. Saladin repays him, gives him gifts, and keeps him as a trusted friend.

**Dioneo's Story (First Day, Fourth Story): A Monk and His Abbot**
Dioneo tells of a lusty young monk in a monastery in Lunigiana who brings a peasant girl to his cell. The abbot discovers them and waits to catch the monk. The monk, realizing he's caught, locks the girl in his cell and gives the abbot his key, asking permission to go to the woods. The abbot, intending to catch the monk red-handed, takes the key, enters the cell, and is himself overcome by lust for the beautiful girl. He engages in intimacy with her. The monk, observing all this, is pardoned by the ashamed abbot, who realizes his own hypocrisy. The girl is released.

**Fiammetta's Story (First Day, Fifth Story): The Marchioness of Monferrato**
Fiammetta narrates how King Philip of France, hearing of the beauty of the Marchioness of Monferrato (whose husband is on crusade), plots to seduce her. He visits her castle unannounced for dinner. The Marchioness, discerning his intent, orders her cooks to prepare only hen dishes. At dinner, the King questions the lack of other fowl. The Marchioness replies that women, like hens, are all "of the same fashion" (implying she is without her "cock" / husband), subtly rebuking his intentions. The King, recognizing her wit and discretion, abandons his pursuit and departs.

**Emilia's Story (First Day, Sixth Story): An Honest Man and a Friar Inquisitor**
Emilia tells of a greedy Friar Inquisitor in Florence who, hearing a rich simple man jokingly claim to have wine Christ might drink, falsely accuses him of blasphemy to extort money. The man, terrified, pays a large bribe. As penance, he must attend mass daily. One day, he hears the Gospel promise of a hundredfold return for good deeds. He tells the inquisitor he pities the friars because they give so much leftover broth to the poor; if they get a hundredfold return, they will drown in it in the afterlife. The angry inquisitor dismisses him.

**Filostrato's Story (First Day, Seventh Story): Bergamino and Messer Cane della Scala**
Filostrato recounts how Messer Cane della Scala, a magnificent but suddenly parsimonious nobleman, dismisses all his entertainers except Bergamino, a witty man, without paying or dismissing him. Bergamino, running out of money, sells his fine clothes. When Messer Cane mockingly asks him what ails him, Bergamino tells a story of Primasso, a scholar, who visited the generous Abbot of Cluny. The Abbot, for the first time, was stingy when he saw Primasso, who, having brought his own bread, ate it. The Abbot then realized his folly and generously rewarded Primasso. Messer Cane understands the implicit rebuke, apologizes for his own parsimony, and generously rewards Bergamino.

**Lauretta's Story (First Day, Eighth Story): Guglielmo Borsiere and Messer Ermino de' Grimaldi**
Lauretta tells of Messer Ermino de' Grimaldi, a rich but extremely avaricious Genoese gentleman. Guglielmo Borsiere, a witty minstrel, visits him. Ermino, showing off his new house, asks Guglielmo to suggest a painting of something "never yet seen." Guglielmo replies that Ermino should have "Liberality" painted, as he has never seen it. Stung by shame, Ermino resolves to change his ways and becomes a generous man.

**Elisa's Story (First Day, Ninth Story): The King of Cyprus and the Gascon Lady**
Elisa tells of the first King of Cyprus, a pusillanimous ruler who tolerated insults. A Gascon lady, having been shamefully abused, seeks justice from him. When she is told of his weakness, she approaches him in tears and asks him to teach her how he endures the insults he receives, so she can learn to bear her own. The King, shamed by her poignant request, awakens to his duties, cruelly avenges her wrong, and becomes a valorous prosecutor of crime.

**Queen Pampinea's Story (First Day, Tenth Story): Master Alberto of Bologna**
Queen Pampinea relates how Master Alberto, an old but famous Bolognese physician, falls in love with the beautiful widow, Madam Malgherida. She and her friends mock him for his age. When they playfully ask him why he loves her, he replies that old men, with more experience, better appreciate beauty. He compares young suitors to eating the bad leaves of a leek while he, the old man, desires the good "head" (implying she might choose him over younger, less substantial men). The ladies are abashed, and the lady promises to be his "creature," respecting his love while preserving her honor.

After the stories, Pampinea appoints Filomena as the next queen. Filomena sets the theme for Day Two: "OF THOSE WHO AFTER BEING BAFFLED BY DIVERS CHANCES HAVE WON AT LAST TO A JOYFUL ISSUE BEYOND THEIR HOPE." Dioneo, keeping his privilege, asks to tell his story last, on a topic of his choosing. The company enjoys bathing, supper, dancing, and Emilia sings a song about self-love.

**Day the Second**
The company enjoys the garden, dines, and reassembles for storytelling. Neifile begins.

**Neifile's Story (Second Day, First Story): Martellino**
Neifile tells of Martellino, a jester, who, with his companions Stecchi and Marchese, comes to Treviso where a supposed saint, Arrigo, is performing miracles. To get close to the saint's body, Martellino feigns being a severely crippled man. He is carried to the body and dramatically "healed" before the crowd. A Florentine recognizes him and exposes the trick. The enraged crowd beats Martellino severely. To save him, Marchese falsely accuses Martellino of being a cutpurse. The Provost's sergeants rescue him from the mob, but the judge tortures him. Martellino cleverly exposes the false accusations by pointing out inconsistencies in the accusers' timelines. With help from a Florentine friend of his companions, Martellino is brought before the Prince, who, amused by the story, releases him and his companions with new clothes. They escape safely.

**Filostrato's Story (Second Day, Second Story): Rinaldo d'Asti**
Filostrato recounts how Rinaldo d'Asti, a merchant, is robbed by highwaymen after boasting of his devotion to Saint Julian. Left in his shirt in the snow outside Castel Guglielmo, he curses the saint. A lady in the castle, whose planned tryst with the Marquis has been canceled, overhears Rinaldo's lamentations while in her bath. She takes pity on him, lets him in, warms him, clothes him, and, finding him handsome, spends the night with him. The next morning, she gives him money and sends him on his way. Coincidentally, the highwaymen are caught for another crime, and Rinaldo's stolen goods are returned to him. He returns home rich, thankful to God and St. Julian.

**Pampinea's Story (Second Day, Third Story): Alessandro and the King's Daughter of England**
Pampinea tells of three Florentine brothers who squander their inheritance, then become rich usurers in England. They send their nephew, Alessandro, to manage their affairs. During a war in England, Alessandro loses everything. His uncles in Florence are imprisoned for debt. Alessandro, returning home in despair, encounters a young "abbot" who is actually the King of England's daughter, fleeing a forced marriage. She falls in love with Alessandro and, after revealing her true identity, proposes marriage. They secretly marry. In Rome, she reveals her identity to the Pope, who blesses their union. They return to Florence, where she frees Alessandro's uncles. Alessandro is honored by the King of England and becomes a powerful lord.

**Lauretta's Story (Second Day, Fourth Story): Landolfo Ruffolo**
Lauretta tells of Landolfo Ruffolo, a rich Ravello merchant who loses his wealth in a trade venture. He turns corsair, becoming rich by plundering Turkish ships. Deciding to retire, he is then robbed by Genoese carracks in the Archipelago. His ship is sunk, and he is taken prisoner. His carrack is wrecked in a storm, but he saves himself by clinging to a chest. He floats to Corfu, where a poor woman rescues him. The chest, opened, is found to be full of precious jewels. Landolfo, now richer than before, rewards the woman and returns home, living in honor.

**Fiammetta's Story (Second Day, Fifth Story): Andreuccio of Perugia**
Fiammetta tells of Andreuccio, a naive horse-courser, who comes to Naples with 500 florins. A cunning Sicilian courtesan, pretending to be his sister, tricks him, takes his money, and causes him to fall into a cesspool. Covered in filth, he encounters two thieves planning to rob an archbishop's tomb. They lower him into a well to clean him, but flee when the watch approaches. The watch, thinking he's a ghost, flees when he climbs out. The thieves return, and force Andreuccio to enter the tomb. He secretly takes a ruby ring. The thieves then abandon him. Another group of thieves arrives, and Andreuccio, scaring them, escapes. He returns to his inn, recovers his stolen goods (from the highwaymen who were caught), and returns home with the ruby, having turned his 500 florins into a valuable gem through a series of misfortunes and lucky escapes.

**Emilia's Story (Second Day, Sixth Story): Madam Beritola**
Emilia relates the long and tragic misfortunes of Madam Beritola, whose husband, Arrighetto Capece, is imprisoned by King Charles. She flees with her two young sons and a nurse, but they are separated by pirates. Beritola is stranded on a desert island and survives with two kidlings. Her sons and nurse are sold into slavery in Genoa. The elder son, Giusfredi (renamed Giannotto), escapes and eventually takes service with Currado Malespina, where his mother, unrecognized, serves as a waiting-woman. Giusfredi falls in love with Currado's daughter, Spina, and they are discovered and imprisoned. During a political upheaval, Giusfredi reveals his true identity. Currado, discovering Giusfredi's noble birth, marries him to Spina. News of Giusfredi's father, Arrighetto, being alive and restored to honor in Sicily, arrives. Scacciato, the younger son, is also found and honorably married. The entire family is reunited and restored to high estate.

**Pamfilo's Story (Second Day, Seventh Story): Alatiel, the Soldan's Daughter**
Pamfilo tells of Alatiel, the beautiful daughter of the Soldan of Babylon, betrothed to the King of Algarve. Her ship is wrecked, and she is the sole survivor among her noble companions. She is found by Pericone, a Majorcan gentleman, who seduces her. He is then murdered by his brother, Marato, who abducts her. Marato is thrown overboard by two Genoese shipmasters, who then fight over her, one killing the other. She is taken to the Prince of Morea, who treats her as his wife. The Duke of Athens, the Prince's kinsman, also falls for her, murders the Prince, and abducts Alatiel. Constantine, the Emperor's son, then abducts her from the Duke. She is captured by the Turks, becomes King Osbech's wife, then, after his death, becomes the lover of his servant, Antiochus. Antiochus dies and leaves her to a Cypriot merchant, who also becomes her lover. Finally, she is recognized by Antigonus, a Cypriot gentleman who once served her father. He helps her concoct a false story of her "virtuous" journey and returns her to her father, who, believing her, sends her to marry the King of Algarve as a "maid."

**Elisa's Story (Second Day, Eighth Story): The Count of Antwerp**
Elisa narrates the story of Gautier, Count of Antwerp, left as Vicar General of France. The King's son's wife falls in love with him and tries to seduce him. He, a loyal man, refuses. She falsely accuses him of attempted rape. Gautier flees with his young children, Louis and Violante, who he renames Perrot and Jeannette, respectively, and instructs them to hide their true identities. He leaves Jeannette with a noble lady in London and Perrot with a Marshal in Wales, then becomes a horseboy in Ireland. Jeannette marries her foster-mother's son, Jamy Lamiens, and Perrot becomes a Marshal, marrying his foster-father's daughter. Eighteen years later, Gautier, as a beggar, sees his children thriving. The Queen of France, on her deathbed, confesses her false accusation. The King offers a reward. Gautier reveals himself to his sons-in-law, insisting they claim the reward to shame the King. He is vindicated, restored to his rank, and his children's noble lineage is revealed.

**Queen Filomena's Story (Second Day, Ninth Story): Ginevra and Bernabo of Genoa**
Queen Filomena tells of Bernabo of Genoa, who boasts of his wife Ginevra's unparalleled chastity. Ambrogiuolo of Piacenza wagers he can corrupt her. He bribes a woman to hide him in a chest in Ginevra's bedchamber. He observes her, notes a mole, and steals her personal items. He returns to Paris and "wins" the wager, convincing Bernabo of Ginevra's infidelity. Bernabo orders his servant to kill Ginevra. The servant, taking pity, lets her go, taking her clothes as proof, and reports she was eaten by wolves. Ginevra, disguised as a man named Sicurano, becomes a trusted officer of the Soldan of Babylon. At a fair, she overhears Ambrogiuolo boasting of his deception. She lures him to Alexandria, arranges for Bernabo to come there, and then, before the Soldan, reveals her true identity and Ambrogiuolo's lies. Ambrogiuolo is executed, and Ginevra is restored to Bernabo, with immense wealth and honor.

**Dioneo's Story (Second Day, Tenth Story): Paganino of Monaco and Messer Ricciardo di Chinzica**
Dioneo tells of Messer Ricciardo di Chinzica, an old, weak judge who marries the young and beautiful Bartolomea. To control her, he enforces a strict "calendar" of fasts and holy days, allowing almost no marital intimacy. She is abducted by Paganino da Mare, a corsair. Paganino, having no such scruples, delights her with his physical attention. She quickly forgets her husband. Ricciardo finds her and offers ransom. Paganino agrees to let her go if she herself wishes. Bartolomea, now content, openly refuses to return to Ricciardo, citing his neglect. Ricciardo, realizing his folly, returns to Pisa and dies of chagrin, while Bartolomea lawfully marries Paganino and lives happily.

At the end of the second day, Dioneo's story entertains but also sparks discussion among the ladies about the nature of marital fidelity. Filomena appoints Neifile as the next queen. Neifile decrees that they will rest from storytelling on Friday (for the Passion of Christ) and Saturday (for hygiene and devotion to the Virgin) and will move to a new, more private location. For Day Three, the theme will be "OF SUCH AS HAVE BY DINT OF DILIGENCE ACQUIRED SOME MUCH DESIRED THING OR RECOVERED SOME LOST GOOD."

**Proem of the Fourth Day (Author's Interruption)**
The author interrupts the narrative to defend himself against critics. He recounts the story of Filippo Balducci, a Roman who raised his son in isolation, teaching him only spiritual matters. When brought to Florence at 18, the son, upon seeing women for the first time, immediately desires one, calling them "green geese." The author uses this to justify his focus on love and women, arguing that natural attraction is undeniable. He also defends his style, age, and choice of subject matter, and dismisses critics as envious or foolish.

**Day the Third**
The company moves to a new, magnificent palace with a beautiful garden, fountain, and diverse animals. They enjoy the scenery and feast. Neifile, the queen, bids Filostrato begin the day's stories.

**Filostrato's Story (Third Day, First Story): Masetto of Lamporecchio**
Filostrato tells of Masetto, a young, handsome laborer, who desires to lie with nuns. He overhears an old gardener complain about the nuns being demanding and about their strict seclusion. Masetto feigns dumbness and gets hired as the new gardener at a convent. The young nuns, believing him to be deaf and dumb and simple-minded, begin to flirt with and then seduce him, curiosity overriding their vows. Two nuns are first, then others join. The abbess herself, seeing Masetto asleep in the garden with his clothes disarranged, is overcome by desire and takes him as her own lover. Masetto, overwhelmed by serving nine women, breaks his silence to the abbess, complaining he cannot satisfy so many. The abbess, realizing the truth, consults with the nuns. To avoid scandal, they pretend Masetto has miraculously regained his speech through their prayers. He is made bailiff, and his duties are arranged to allow him to satisfy them all discreetly. He returns home rich and a father, having used his youth wisely.

**Pampinea's Story (Third Day, Second Story): A Horsekeeper and King Agilulf's Wife**
Pampinea tells of a horsekeeper who falls in love with Queen Theodolinda, wife of King Agilulf of the Lombards. He observes the King's discreet visits to the Queen: wrapped in a mantle, carrying a taper and a wand, he taps the door twice. The horsekeeper procures similar attire, washes himself, and imitates the King. The chamberwoman opens the door, takes the taper, and he enters. He lies with the Queen, who mistakes him for her husband. The King, returning later, is told by the Queen he has already visited her more ardently than usual. The King, realizing he's been cuckolded but wishing to avoid scandal, silently resolves to find the culprit. He searches the servants' dormitory, feeling their pulses. He finds the horsekeeper's pulse still racing and clips a lock of his hair to mark him. The horsekeeper, realizing he's been found out, clips a lock from every other servant's hair. The next morning, the King, seeing many men with clipped hair, realizes his servant's cleverness. He subtly warns the culprit to desist, preferring quiet discretion to public shame.

**Filomena's Story (Third Day, Third Story): A Lady and a Grave Friar**
Filomena recounts how a noble Florentine lady, unhappily married to a wool-monger and enamored of a gentleman, uses a naive but well-reputed friar as an unwitting go-between. She confesses to the friar, "complaining" that the gentleman constantly pursues her, disturbing her honor. The friar, believing her, sternly rebukes the gentleman, who immediately understands the lady's clever device. He begins to visit her, under the guise of being "chastised." Later, the lady "complains" again to the friar that the gentleman has sent her gifts. The friar, again deceived, takes the gifts and returns them to the gentleman, unknowingly facilitating their communication and intimacy. Finally, the lady tells the friar that the gentleman tried to enter her room via the garden window. The friar, enraged, confronts the gentleman, who, now having full assurance of the lady's love and her husband's absence, uses the friar's instructions to meet her in the garden that night. They spend the night together, mocking the simple friar.

**Pamfilo's Story (Third Day, Fourth Story): Dom Felice and Fra Puccio**
Pamfilo tells of Fra Puccio, a rich, ignorant, and devout tertiary of St. Francis, who neglects his young, beautiful wife, Isabetta, for religious practices. Dom Felice, a clever conventual monk, befriends Fra Puccio. Desiring Isabetta, Dom Felice invents a penance for Fra Puccio: he must stand cruciform in a secluded part of his house from complines until matins for forty days, abstaining from his wife, to cleanse past sins and ensure future ones are venial. Fra Puccio, eager for sainthood, eagerly undertakes this. Meanwhile, Dom Felice secretly visits Isabetta nightly, bringing food and drink, and satisfying her desires. One night, Fra Puccio hears them and asks his wife what she's doing. She replies she's "tossing," explaining "who suppeth not by night must toss till morning light." Fra Puccio, believing her to be suffering from hunger due to her fasting, urges her to rest. The monk and lady continue their affair discreetly until the penance ends. The lady, having enjoyed the monk's "fare," continues to meet him, pleased with the "paradise" they have found.

**Elisa's Story (Third Day, Fifth Story): Ricciardo, Surnamed Il Zima**
Elisa tells of Messer Francesco Vergellesi, a rich but avaricious gentleman of Pistoia, who desires Ricciardo (Il Zima)'s fine palfrey. Il Zima, who loves Messer Francesco's virtuous wife, Caterina, offers the horse as a gift if he can speak with Caterina alone in her husband's presence, but unheard by others. Messer Francesco agrees, intending to outwit him, and instructs Caterina not to speak a word. Il Zima delivers a passionate declaration of love. Caterina remains silent, but her sighs and glances betray her awakened feelings. Il Zima, realizing the husband's trick, cunningly replies to himself, as if Caterina is speaking, promising to yield to his love after her husband departs for Milan in a few days. He tells himself to look for two napkins displayed in her window as a signal. Messer Francesco, believing Caterina to be a "marble statue," claims the horse. A few days later, he leaves for Milan. Caterina, now moved by Il Zima's love and her husband's neglect, displays the napkins. Il Zima comes, they become lovers, and continue their trysts while her husband is away and even after his return.

**Fiammetta's Story (Third Day, Sixth Story): Ricciardo Minutolo and Catella**
Fiammetta tells of Ricciardo Minutolo, a noble Neapolitan, who loves Catella, wife of Filippello Fighinolfi. Catella is fiercely faithful and jealous of her husband. Ricciardo, learning of her jealousy, feigns despair and courts another woman publicly. Catella, convinced he no longer loves her, becomes friendly with him. Ricciardo then subtly implies that Filippello is pursuing his (Ricciardo's) wife. Catella, consumed by jealousy, presses him for details. Ricciardo, promising secrecy, reveals that Filippello has arranged a tryst with his (Ricciardo's) wife in a certain bathhouse the next day at noon. He suggests Catella go in her place to shame Filippello. Catella, enraged, agrees. Ricciardo arranges with the bathhouse keeper. Catella arrives, believing Filippello is inside. She enters a dark room and embraces Ricciardo, mistaking him for her husband. She passionately rages at him for his supposed infidelity, boasting of her love for him (thinking it's Filippello) and her cleverness in catching him. Ricciardo, enjoying her fury, finally reveals his identity. Catella is furious but, realizing her predicament and the potential for scandal and violence, makes peace with him. She finds the experience pleasurable and continues her affair with Ricciardo discreetly.

**Emilia's Story (Third Day, Seventh Story): Tedaldo Elisei and Madam Ermellina**
Emilia relates how Tedaldo Elisei, a Florentine nobleman, deeply loved Madam Ermellina, a married lady. She initially returned his affection but then cruelly rejected him. Heartbroken, Tedaldo leaves Florence for seven years, becoming a rich merchant in Cyprus. Hearing a song about his past love, he is overcome with desire to see her again. He returns to Florence disguised as a pilgrim. He learns his brothers are mourning him, having buried a stranger in his place, and that Ermellina's husband, Aldobrandino Palermini, has been falsely accused and imprisoned for Tedaldo's "murder." Tedaldo, from his inn, overhears the true murderers (two innkeepers and their servant) confessing their crime. He visits Ermellina as a "prophet," chastising her for her past cruelty towards him and for believing a "scurvy friar" who made her abandon him. He assures her he is not dead. He then reveals his true identity. Ermellina, astonished, embraces him. Tedaldo, still as a pilgrim, goes to the authorities, reveals the truth, and secures Aldobrandino's release. He then arranges a banquet for his brothers and Aldobrandino, where he reveals his identity to them. He reconciles his brothers with Aldobrandino. Tedaldo and Ermellina resume their discreet love affair, living happily.

**Lauretta's Story (Third Day, Eighth Story): Ferondo and the Abbot**
Lauretta tells of Ferondo, a wealthy but foolish and extremely jealous farmer, whose beautiful wife is desired by the abbot of a nearby monastery. The abbot, a holy man in public but lustful in private, devises a plan. He tells the wife that to cure Ferondo's jealousy, he must "go to purgatory" (i.e., appear to die and then be revived). The wife agrees, asking for one night's reward: her love. The abbot gives Ferondo a powerful sleeping powder (from the Old Man of the Mountain) in wine, making him appear dead for three days. Ferondo is buried. The abbot secretly removes him, dresses him as a monk, and imprisons him in a dark vault, where a Bolognese monk (his accomplice) is to attend him. The abbot then secretly visits Ferondo's wife for many nights. The Bolognese monk repeatedly beats Ferondo and tells him he is in purgatory, being punished for jealousy. Ferondo, bewildered, believes him. After the wife becomes pregnant, the abbot revives Ferondo with a weaker potion and returns him to his tomb. Ferondo "rises from the dead," believing he has been in purgatory. He is now cured of his jealousy. He is overjoyed to be back and believes his wife is pregnant by him. The abbot's sanctity is greatly enhanced. The wife discreetly continues her affair with the abbot.

**Queen Neifile's Story (Third Day, Ninth Story): Gillette de Narbonne**
Queen Neifile relates how Gillette de Narbonne, a physician's daughter, secretly loves Bertrand de Roussillon, a noble orphaned youth raised in her father's house. Bertrand becomes a ward of the King of France. Gillette's father dies. The King of France suffers from an incurable fistula. Gillette, using her father's medical knowledge, creates a cure. She travels to Paris, offers to cure the King, and demands Bertrand as her husband if she succeeds. The King, skeptical but desperate, agrees. Gillette cures him within eight days. Bertrand, disdainful of her lower birth, refuses to marry her. The King forces him. Bertrand marries her against his will, but immediately flees to Florence to serve in a war, vowing never to return to her until she has his ring on her finger and a son by him in her arms (conditions he believes impossible). Gillette, a capable lady, manages his county admirably. She then goes to Florence, disguised as a pilgrim, and learns Bertrand is pursuing a noble but poor Florentine lady. Gillette, with the help of the lady's mother, takes the place of the lover's mistress in bed, obtains Bertrand's ring, and conceives two sons by him. She presents herself to Bertrand, fulfilling his conditions. Bertrand, seeing her patience and the children, accepts her as his wife, and they live happily.

**Dioneo's Story (Third Day, Tenth Story): Alibech and Rustico**
Dioneo tells a very explicit story of Alibech, a beautiful, naive young girl from Capsa in Barbary. Hearing Christians praise serving God, she goes to the desert of Thebais to learn. She meets Rustico, a young hermit. Rustico, overcome with lust, devises a "service of God": he teaches Alibech to "put the devil in hell" (euphemism for sexual intercourse). Alibech, in her innocence, eagerly participates, finding the "service" very sweet. Rustico, however, becomes exhausted. He tells her the "devil" is chastened and needs no more "putting in hell." Alibech, her "hell" (sexual desire) still raging, insists he continue. Meanwhile, Alibech's family in Capsa perishes in a fire, leaving her a rich heir. Neerbale, a young man who squandered his wealth, finds her in the desert and, despite her reluctance, brings her back and marries her. When asked about serving God, she explains she "put the devil in hell." The women of Capsa, amused, adopt the phrase, and it becomes a common saying.

At the end of the third day, Dioneo's story causes much laughter among the ladies. Neifile appoints Filostrato as the new king. Filostrato, revealing his own history of unhappy loves, sets the theme for Day Four: "OF THOSE WHOSE LOVES HAVE HAD UNHAPPY ENDING." Lauretta sings a plaintive song lamenting her own unhappy love and the loss of her former happiness.

**Day the Fourth**
The author provides a proem, defending himself against critics who accuse him of overmuch license, pleasing women too much, and writing frivolous stories unsuitable for his age. He recounts the partial story of Filippo Balducci, who raised his son in isolation from women, only for the son to immediately desire "green geese" (women) upon seeing them in Florence. This illustrates the irrepressible nature of human desire and justifies his focus on love. The day's storytelling then begins under King Filostrato's governance.

**Fiammetta's Story (Fourth Day, First Story): Tancred and Ghismonda**
Fiammetta tells the tragic story of Tancred, Prince of Salerno, and his daughter Ghismonda. Tancred, loving his daughter too much, delays her marriage. After being widowed, Ghismonda secretly falls in love with Guiscardo, a man of humble birth but noble spirit. They meet in secret via a hidden grotto. Tancred discovers them, hidden in his daughter's chamber. Filled with rage, he has Guiscardo secretly strangled and sends Ghismonda his heart in a golden bowl. Ghismonda, with stoic resolve, pours poisonous water over the heart, drinks it, and dies by her beloved's side, requesting to be buried with him. Tancred, remorseful, buries them in a single tomb.

**Pampinea's Story (Fourth Day, Second Story): Fra Alberto**
Pampinea recounts the story of Fra Alberto, a hypocritical friar in Venice who feigns sanctity. He desires Madam Lisetta, a vain and foolish lady. He pretends to be the angel Gabriel, claiming to take over his body to visit her. Lisetta, believing him, joyfully receives him for intimate trysts. She boasts of her divine lover to a gossip, who spreads the tale. Lisetta's brothers-in-law, hearing the rumors, ambush Fra Alberto. He escapes by jumping into the Grand Canal and takes refuge with a poor man. The man, realizing who he is, blackmails him and then forces him to participate in a public festival disguised as a "wild man of the woods." Fra Alberto is unmasked, humiliated, and eventually imprisoned by his brethren.

**Lauretta's Story (Fourth Day, Third Story): Three Young Men and Three Sisters**
Lauretta tells of three sisters in Marseilles – Ninetta, Maddalena, and Bertella – who fall in love with three young men – Restagnone, Folco, and Ughetto. They steal their father's wealth and flee to Crete to live together. Restagnone, growing weary of Ninetta, falls in love with another. Ninetta, consumed by jealousy, poisons him. The Duke of Crete discovers her crime and imprisons her. Maddalena, to save her sister, yields to the Duke's long-standing desires. The Duke, after sleeping with Maddalena, releases Ninetta. Folco, Maddalena's lover, discovers the truth and, enraged, kills Maddalena. He then flees with Ninetta. Ughetto and Bertella are falsely accused of Maddalena's murder, imprisoned, and eventually bribe their way to freedom, fleeing to Rhodes where they die in poverty.

**Elisa's Story (Fourth Day, Fourth Story): Gerbino and the King of Tunis's Daughter**
Elisa tells of Gerbino, King Guglielmo of Sicily's grandson, who falls in love with the beautiful daughter of the King of Tunis, solely by reputation. She returns his love. Her father betroths her to the King of Granada. Gerbino, defying his grandfather's pledge to the King of Tunis, attacks her ship at sea to abduct her. The Saracens, to spite him, murder the princess before his eyes and throw her body into the sea. Gerbino, enraged, boards the ship, slays many, retrieves her body, and buries her. The King of Tunis complains to King Guglielmo, who, upholding his honor, condemns Gerbino to death, and he is beheaded.

**Filomena's Story (Fourth Day, Fifth Story): Lisabetta and Lorenzo**
Filomena narrates the tragic love of Lisabetta and Lorenzo in Messina. Lisabetta's three merchant brothers, to protect their honor, murder Lorenzo and bury him secretly when they discover his affair with their sister. Lorenzo appears to Lisabetta in a dream, revealing his murder and burial place. Lisabetta secretly disinters his head, takes it home, and buries it in a pot of basil, which she constantly waters with her tears and tends with obsessive devotion. Her brothers, noticing her strange behavior and wasting health, discover the head. Fearing scandal, they throw it away and flee to Naples. Lisabetta, heartbroken, dies of grief, still lamenting her lost basil pot.

**Pamfilo's Story (Fourth Day, Sixth Story): Andrevuola and Gabriotto**
Pamfilo tells of Andrevuola of Brescia, who secretly marries her lover, Gabriotto. She dreams he is taken from her by a dark, frightful thing. He, in turn, dreams of a black greyhound tearing out his heart. Soon after, while they are in the garden, Gabriotto suddenly dies in her arms. Andrevuola, to preserve his honor and their secret, takes his body to his house. She is intercepted by the police. At the Provost's palace, physicians confirm he died of natural causes. The Provost attempts to seduce Andrevuola, but she bravely resists. Her father arrives, is reconciled with her, and orders an honorable burial for Gabriotto. Andrevuola, rejecting the Provost's suit, becomes a nun.

**Emilia's Story (Fourth Day, Seventh Story): Simona and Pasquino**
Emilia relates the story of Simona, a poor Florentine spinner, who loves Pasquino, a young wool-monger. They meet in a garden under a sage bush. Pasquino rubs a sage leaf on his teeth and suddenly dies, swelling and turning dark. Simona is accused of poisoning him. At her trial, to demonstrate her innocence, she rubs a leaf from the same sage bush on her teeth and dies on the spot. The judge orders the bush cut down, revealing a giant toad whose poisonous breath had made the sage venomous. Simona and Pasquino are buried together.

**Neifile's Story (Fourth Day, Eighth Story): Girolamo and Salvestra**
Neifile tells of Girolamo, a rich Florentine youth, who falls in love with Salvestra, a tailor's daughter. His mother sends him to Paris to break off the match. He returns two years later to find Salvestra married. He visits her secretly at night. She, though still caring for him, asks him to leave to protect her marriage. Girolamo, heartbroken, silently dies by her side. Salvestra, fearing scandal, awakens her husband and, feigning a hypothetical situation, gets him to agree to carry the body home. He does so. In the morning, Girolamo is found dead. Salvestra, overcome with grief at his funeral, throws herself on his body and dies. They are buried together.

**King Filostrato's Story (Fourth Day, Ninth Story): Sir Guillaume de Roussillon and Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing**
King Filostrato recounts the tragic tale of two Provençal knights, Sir Guillaume de Roussillon and Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing, who are close friends. Roussillon's wife and Guardestaing become secret lovers. Roussillon discovers them and, filled with hatred, ambushes and kills Guardestaing. He extracts Guardestaing's heart, has it cooked, and serves it to his wife. When she praises the dish, he reveals it is her lover's heart. Horrified, she declares no other food will follow such noble meat and throws herself from a high window, dying instantly. Roussillon flees. The lovers are buried together.

**Dioneo's Story (Fourth Day, Tenth Story): The Physician's Wife**
Dioneo tells of Master Mazzeo, an old Salerno surgeon, whose young wife, neglected by him, takes a lover, Ruggieri. The doctor prepares a powerful sleeping potion. Ruggieri, thirsty, drinks it, falls into a deep sleep, and appears dead. The wife and her maid hide him in a chest outside. Two usurers steal the chest and take it home. Ruggieri awakes inside the usurers' house, is discovered, and falsely accused of theft. He is tortured and condemned to hang. The maid, after securing her mistress's and the doctor's forgiveness for her part in Ruggieri being in the house (by claiming to have brought him for herself), confesses the full story to the prefect of police (after offering him sexual favors). Ruggieri is released, the usurers are fined, and the wife continues her discreet affair.

The day ends with the company's laughter providing relief from the sad stories. Filostrato appoints Fiammetta as the next queen, hoping she will bring them cheer. Fiammetta sets the theme for Day Five: "OF THAT WHICH HATH HAPPILY BETIDED LOVERS AFTER SUNDRY CRUEL AND MISFORTUNATE ADVENTURES." Filostrato sings a sorrowful song about his own unhappy love.

**Day the Fifth**
The company wakes early, enjoys the garden, dines, and reassembles for storytelling. Queen Fiammetta bids Pamfilo begin.

**Pamfilo's Story (Fifth Day, First Story): Cimon and Iphigenia**
Pamfilo tells of Cimon, a dull-witted Cypriot nobleman's son, known as "brute beast." He discovers the beautiful Iphigenia asleep in a wood, and her beauty awakens his intelligence. He transforms into a refined and accomplished gentleman. When Iphigenia is betrothed to Pasimondas of Rhodes, Cimon abducts her at sea. A storm drives his ship to Rhodes, where he is captured and imprisoned. Lysimachus, a Rhodian magistrate who also loves a betrothed lady (Cassandra, Pasimondas's brother's fiancée), frees Cimon and conspires with him. They interrupt the double wedding, abduct Iphigenia and Cassandra, kill Pasimondas and his brother, and flee to Crete. There, Cimon marries Iphigenia, and Lysimachus marries Cassandra. After some time, their families reconcile, and they return home to live happily.

**Emilia's Story (Fifth Day, Second Story): Costanza and Martuccio Gomito**
Emilia relates the love of Costanza and Martuccio Gomito of Lipari. Martuccio, rejected by Costanza's father for being poor, becomes a corsair but is captured and imprisoned in Tunis. News of his supposed death reaches Lipari. Costanza, despairing, sets adrift in a small boat, hoping to die. She is carried by wind to Susa, near Tunis, and is rescued by a kind woman. Martuccio, in Tunis, offers military counsel to King Mariabdela, enabling the King to win a war. Martuccio rises to high favor. Costanza hears he is alive and powerful. She travels to Tunis, reveals herself to him, and they are joyfully reunited. The King blesses their marriage and gives them gifts. They return to Lipari, marry, and live happily.

**Elisa's Story (Fifth Day, Third Story): Pietro Boccamazza and Agnolella**
Elisa tells of Pietro Boccamazza, a Roman gentleman, who elopes with Agnolella, a commoner's beautiful daughter, due to family disapproval. On their journey, they are ambushed by robbers. Agnolella flees into a wood, escapes, and is eventually sheltered by the wife of Lionello di Campodifiore, a nobleman. Pietro is captured by another group of robbers, escapes during a fight, and wanders lost in the wood. He spends a terrifying night in an oak tree, witnessing wolves devour his horse. He eventually reaches Lionello's castle and is joyfully reunited with Agnolella. Lionello's wife, taking pity, marries them, and they return to Rome, reconciled with their families, and live happily.

**Filostrato's Story (Fifth Day, Fourth Story): Ricciardo Manardi and Caterina**
Filostrato relates how Ricciardo Manardi falls in love with Caterina, daughter of Messer Lizio da Valbona. Caterina, kept under strict watch, complains of the summer heat and asks to sleep in a gallery overlooking her father's garden to hear the nightingale. Her parents reluctantly agree. Ricciardo climbs to the gallery and spends the night with Caterina, "making the nightingale sing many a time." Messer Lizio discovers them naked and entwined at dawn. Instead of rage, he pragmatically decides to marry Ricciardo to Caterina, as he is young, rich, and noble. They are married on the spot, and later formally, living a long and happy life together.

**Neifile's Story (Fifth Day, Fifth Story): Giannole di Severino and Minghino di Mingole**
Neifile tells of Guidotto da Cremona, who leaves his young daughter, Agnesa, to his friend Giacomino da Pavia. Giacomino raises her in Faenza. Two young men, Giannole di Severino and Minghino di Mingole, fall in love with Agnesa, but their families object to her unknown origins. Both try to abduct her. One night, a fight breaks out between their factions. During the ensuing investigation, Giacomino reveals how Guidotto found Agnesa as a child in a plundered house in Faenza. A witness recognizes the story and identifies Agnesa's true father, Bernabuccio, who is present. Agnesa is reunited with her family. The town-captain releases the young men. Minghino, the more honorable of the two, marries Agnesa, and they live happily.

**Pampinea's Story (Fifth Day, Sixth Story): Gianni di Procida and Restituta**
Pampinea recounts how Gianni di Procida and Restituta, young lovers from Ischia, are separated when Restituta is abducted by pirates and given to King Frederick of Sicily. Gianni searches for her and discovers her location. He secretly enters the King's garden and chamber to be with her. They fall asleep in each other's arms. King Frederick discovers them. Enraged, he orders them to be publicly bound and burned. Ruggieri dell' Oria, the King's admiral, recognizes Gianni and intercedes, reminding the King of Gianni's uncle's service (which helped Frederick gain the throne). The King, recognizing his obligations and moved by the lovers' plight, pardons them, marries them, and sends them home with gifts.

**Lauretta's Story (Fifth Day, Seventh Story): Teodoro and Violante**
Lauretta tells of Teodoro, an Armenian nobleman's son, captured by corsairs and sold as a slave to Messer Amerigo in Sicily, where he is renamed Pietro. He falls in love with Messer Amerigo's daughter, Violante, and she with him. They become secret lovers, and Violante becomes pregnant. Pietro fears for his life. Violante gives birth. Messer Amerigo discovers her pregnancy and, enraged, threatens her. She reveals Pietro is the father. Pietro is arrested, tortured, and condemned to flogging and hanging. As he is led to execution, his real father, Fineo, an Armenian ambassador, recognizes him by a birthmark. Fineo intervenes, revealing Pietro's noble birth and willingness to marry Violante. Messer Amerigo, ashamed, and learning his daughter and grandson are safe, agrees to the marriage. Teodoro and Violante marry and return to Armenia with Fineo, living happily.

**Filomena's Story (Fifth Day, Eighth Story): Nastagio degli Onesti**
Filomena narrates how Nastagio degli Onesti of Ravenna, heartbroken by the cruel rejection of his beloved, a daughter of Messer Paolo Traversari, retreats to his country estate. One Friday, in a pine-wood, he witnesses a terrifying vision: a knight, Messer Guido degli Anastagi, eternally pursuing and brutally dismembering a naked lady (his former cruel mistress) with dogs, as punishment for her cruelty towards him. The lady then revives, and the chase resumes. Nastagio, realizing this is a divine judgment, arranges a grand dinner in the same wood for his beloved and her family on the following Friday. The family witnesses the horrific scene. Nastagio's cruel mistress, terrified of suffering a similar fate, changes her heart and agrees to marry Nastagio. They live long and happily, and this event makes all the ladies of Ravenna more compliant to men's desires.

**Queen Fiammetta's Story (Fifth Day, Ninth Story): Federigo degli Alberighi**
Queen Fiammetta tells of Federigo degli Alberighi, a Florentine nobleman who squanders his fortune trying to win the love of Madam Giovanna. Left with only a small farm and a prized falcon, he lives in poverty. Madam Giovanna's husband dies, leaving her a son. Her son falls ill and desires Federigo's falcon, believing it will cure him. Giovanna, despite her reluctance to ask Federigo for his last possession, visits him. Federigo, overjoyed by her visit but having nothing else to offer, kills and roasts his falcon to serve to her. Giovanna, realizing his sacrifice, is deeply moved. Her son dies without the falcon. Later, her brothers urge her to remarry. She, admiring Federigo's magnanimity, declares she will marry only him, preferring "a man that lacketh of riches than riches that lack of a man." She marries Federigo, making him rich again, and they live happily.

**Dioneo's Story (Fifth Day, Tenth Story): Pietro di Vinciolo and his Wife**
Dioneo tells of Pietro di Vinciolo of Perugia, an effeminate man who neglects his lusty young wife. The wife, with the help of a procuress, takes a lover. One evening, Pietro unexpectedly returns while the lover is in the house. The wife hides him under a hen-coop. Pietro tells her he's just sold an old vat. She quickly claims she sold it for more to a man who is currently inside it checking its soundness. Pietro, keen on the extra money, agrees to clean the vat himself. While Pietro is inside the vat scraping, his wife positions herself at the opening, blocking his view, and the lover emerges from under the coop to have sexual relations with her, with Pietro literally beneath them. An ass accidentally steps on the lover's fingers, causing him to cry out. Pietro discovers the lover. His wife, undaunted, verbally chastises him for his own neglect and hypocrisy. Pietro, realizing he is outwitted and more interested in his own "lewd ends," makes peace with her, allowing her freedom as long as she is discreet.

At the conclusion of the fifth day, Dioneo's explicit story draws laughter. Fiammetta appoints Elisa as the new queen. Elisa proposes that for Day Six, they tell "OF WHOSO, BEING ASSAILED WITH SOME JIBING SPEECH, HATH VINDICATED HIMSELF OR HATH WITH SOME READY REPLY OR ADVISEMENT ESCAPED LOSS, PERIL OR SHAME." The company agrees, and after supper and entertainment, they retire.

**Day the Sixth**
The company enjoys a morning walk, dines, and reassembles for storytelling. A commotion in the kitchen leads to Licisca, an old serving-woman, arguing with Tindaro about whether women are chaste before marriage. Licisca asserts that "not a single gossip who went a maid to her husband" and that women frequently deceive their husbands. Dioneo, as a joke, declares Licisca in the right. Queen Elisa then bids Filomena begin the day's stories.

**Filomena's Story (Sixth Day, First Story): Madam Oretta**
Filomena tells of Madam Oretta, a noble Florentine lady, who is traveling with a company of gentlemen. One gentleman, boasting he will carry her "a-horseback" with one of the finest stories, begins to narrate a tale but does so extremely poorly, repeating himself and mixing up details. Madam Oretta, exasperated, interrupts him pleasantly, saying, "Sir, this horse of yours hath too hard a trot; wherefore I pray you be pleased to set me down." The gentleman, understanding her witty rebuke, stops the story and changes the subject.

**Pampinea's Story (Sixth Day, Second Story): Cisti the Baker**
Pampinea recounts how Cisti, a wealthy baker with a noble spirit, has the finest wines in Florence. Messer Geri Spina, a nobleman, and papal ambassadors pass Cisti's shop daily. Cisti, too humble to invite them directly, subtly entices Messer Geri by visibly enjoying his wine each morning. Messer Geri eventually asks for a taste, is impressed, and often drinks with Cisti. Later, Messer Geri holds a banquet and sends a servant with a large flagon to Cisti for wine. Cisti refuses, saying Messer Geri did not send the servant to him, but to the Arno (implying the large flagon is for the servants, not the fine wine). Messer Geri realizes his error, sends a proper smaller flask, and Cisti generously fills it. Cisti then sends a small cask of the wine to Messer Geri, apologizing for his earlier refusal. Messer Geri holds Cisti in high esteem.

**Lauretta's Story (Sixth Day, Third Story): Madam Nonna de' Pulci**
Lauretta tells of Messer Dego della Ratta, a Catalan marshal, who, desiring a noble Florentine lady (the bishop's niece), pays her miserly husband 500 gilded silver coins to lie with her. The affair becomes public, shaming the husband and the bishop. Later, the bishop, riding with the marshal, sees Madam Nonna de' Pulci, a witty and spirited lady. He points her out to the marshal and asks Nonna if she could "make a conquest" of him. Nonna, perceiving the insult (linking her to the marshal's known indiscretion), retorts, "Maybe, sir, he would not make a conquest of me; but, in any case, I should want good money." Both the bishop (for his kinswoman's dishonor) and the marshal (for his payment) are shamed into silence.

**Neifile's Story (Sixth Day, Fourth Story): Chichibio the Cook**
Neifile recounts how Currado Gianfigliazzi, a noble Florentine, catches a crane and orders his cook, Chichibio, to roast it. Chichibio, enamored of a neighborhood wench named Brunetta, gives her one of the crane's thighs. When Currado sees the thighless crane, Chichibio boldly claims cranes have only one leg. Currado, angered, threatens punishment unless Chichibio can prove it. The next morning, Currado takes Chichibio to a river where cranes are sleeping on one leg. Chichibio points them out. Currado shouts, and the cranes put down their other leg and fly away. Chichibio quickly retorts that Currado didn't shout at the previous night's crane. Currado, amused, pardons him.

**Pamfilo's Story (Sixth Day, Fifth Story): Messer Forese da Rabatta and Master Giotto**
Pamfilo tells of Messer Forese da Rabatta, an excellent but ugly lawyer, and Master Giotto, the renowned painter, who is also ill-favored. They are returning from Mugello on horseback when caught in a sudden rain shower. They borrow old cloaks and hats and continue, drenched and muddy. Messer Forese, looking at Giotto's disheveled appearance, jokes, "How sayst thou, Giotto? An there encountered us here a stranger who had never seen thee, thinkest thou he would believe thee to be, as thou art, the finest painter in the world?" Giotto quickly replies, "Ay, sir, methinketh he might e'en believe it whenas, looking upon you, he should believe that you knew your A B C." Messer Forese, realizing his own ugliness, understands the sharp retort.

**Fiammetta's Story (Sixth Day, Sixth Story): Michele Scalza and the Cadgers**
Fiammetta recounts how Michele Scalza, a witty young Florentine, argues with friends about who are the oldest and best gentlemen in Florence. When others name noble families, Scalza laughs and declares that the "Cadgers" (professional beggars of Santa Maria Maggiore) are the oldest and noblest gentlemen in the world. He wagers a supper on it. His friend, Neri Mannini, accepts. Scalza "proves" his point by arguing that God created the Cadgers when he was first learning to draw (explaining their distorted faces), and all other men after He learned. Therefore, Cadgers are older and nobler. The judge and others, amused, concede Scalza has won the supper.

**Filostrato's Story (Sixth Day, Seventh Story): Madam Filippa**
Filostrato tells of Madam Filippa of Prato, who is found by her husband, Rinaldo de' Pugliesi, in bed with her lover, Lazzerino. Prato's cruel statute condemned adulterous wives to be burned. Rinaldo accuses her. Filippa, with great courage, insists on appearing in court. Before the provost, she admits her adultery but argues that the law is unjust because women had no say in its creation. She then asks her husband if he has always taken his pleasure of her whenever he wished. He admits she has. Filippa then asks the provost what she should do with the "rest" of her body and desires, implying it's better to gratify a lover than let it go to waste. The crowd, amused, agrees. The statute is modified to apply only to women who sell their favors for money. Filippa returns home in triumph.

**Emilia's Story (Sixth Day, Eighth Story): Fresco and Ciesca**
Emilia relates how Fresco da Celatico has a vain, prideful, and hypercritical niece named Ciesca. She constantly finds fault with everyone and everything she sees. One day, Ciesca returns home, complaining that Florence is full of "disagreeable and tiresome people" and that she hates seeing them. Fresco, displeased by her airs, tells her, "My lass, if disagreeable folk be so distasteful to thee as thou sayest, never mirror thyself in the glass, so thou wouldst live merry." Ciesca, being dull-witted, fails to understand the witty insult and continues in her folly.

**Queen Elisa's Story (Sixth Day, Ninth Story): Guido Cavalcanti**
Queen Elisa recounts how Florentine gentlemen, including Messer Betto Brunelleschi, try to engage Guido Cavalcanti, a renowned logician and philosopher, in their merry company. Guido, often lost in thought (and suspected of Epicurean views, i.e., doubting God's existence), rejects them. One day, Messer Betto and his company, riding past the tombs outside San Giovanni, accost Guido, who is deep in thought among them. They mock him, saying, "Guido, thou refusest to be of our company; but, harkye, whenas thou shalt have found that God is not, what wilt thou have accomplished?" Guido, hemmed in, leaps nimbly over a tomb and replies, "Gentlemen, you may say what you will to me in your own house." He escapes. The gentlemen are initially confused, but Messer Betto interprets Guido's retort: the tombs are the "houses of the dead," and by saying they are in "their own house," Guido implied that they, being ignorant and unlettered compared to him, are "worse than dead folk." They are shamed and leave him alone.

**Dioneo's Story (Sixth Day, Tenth Story): Fra Cipolla**
Dioneo tells of Fra Cipolla, a friar of St. Anthony, known for his witty sermons and collecting alms. He promises the simple country folk of Certaldo that he will show them a feather of the Angel Gabriel (which he claims remained in the Virgin Mary's chamber). Two roguish youths, Giovanni and Biagio, decide to play a trick on him. While Fra Cipolla is at dinner, they bribe his slovenly servant, Guccio, and steal the feather from his saddle-bags, replacing it with coals. After dinner, Fra Cipolla begins his sermon, praising the Angel Gabriel. When he opens the casket, he finds coals. Without missing a beat, he improvises a new story: he claims he carries two relics, the Angel Gabriel's feather and coals from St. Lawrence's gridiron, which are so similar he accidentally brought the wrong one. He then proclaims that these coals are a more appropriate relic for the upcoming Feast of St. Lawrence, and that whoever is marked with them will be protected from fire. The credulous crowd, even more impressed, offers him better alms. He marks them all with crosses. The youths, present, laugh heartily at his ingenious quick-wittedness.

At the end of the sixth day, Dioneo's story leaves the company laughing. Elisa appoints Dioneo as the new king. Dioneo, in a jovial but firm manner, sets the theme for Day Seven: "OF THE TRICKS WHICH, OR FOR LOVE OR FOR THEIR OWN PRESERVATION, WOMEN HAVE HERETOFORE PLAYED THEIR HUSBANDS, WITH OR WITHOUT THE LATTER'S COGNIZANCE THEREOF." He defends his choice, saying the times allow for such discourse, and their company is virtuous enough not to be corrupted. The ladies then visit the "Ladies' Valley," a beautiful, secluded spot where they bathe naked in a lake. Later, they return to the palace for supper and dancing. Elisa sings a plaintive song about being trapped by love and suffering under a harsh lover.

**Day the Seventh**
The company travels to the Ladies' Valley, enjoying its beauty, dining by the lake, and then reassembling for storytelling. King Dioneo bids Emilia begin.

**Emilia's Story (Seventh Day, First Story): Gianni Lotteringhi**
Emilia tells of Gianni Lotteringhi, a simple-minded Florentine wool-comber, and his discreet wife, Tessa, who has a lover, Federigo. They devise a signal: an ass's skull in a vineyard, turned towards Florence, means Gianni is away; if towards Fiesole, he is home. One night, Federigo comes for a tryst, but Gianni unexpectedly returns. Tessa hides Federigo in the garden. When Gianni hears a knock, Tessa feigns fear, claiming it's a phantom. She suggests they "exorcise" it with a special orison she learned. At the door, she performs a conjuration aloud, directing the "phantom" (Federigo) to the garden, where he will find "an anointed twice-anointed one" (capons) and "an hundred turds of my sitting hen" (eggs) and wine, and to leave them alone. Federigo, who hears this, realizes her meaning, takes the food from the garden, and dines at his ease.

**Filostrato's Story (Seventh Day, Second Story): Peronella**
Filostrato recounts how Peronella, a poor but beautiful Neapolitan mason's wife, takes a lover, Giannello Strignario. They arrange to meet when her husband leaves for work. One morning, the husband unexpectedly returns while Giannello is inside. Peronella quickly hides Giannello in a large vat. She then opens the door, scolding her husband for returning early and neglecting her. He explains he has sold the old vat to a man for five florins. Quick-witted, Peronella claims she sold it for seven florins to a man who is currently inside checking its soundness. The husband is pleased. Giannello emerges, pretending to be the buyer, and complains the vat is dirty. The husband, eager for the seven florins, agrees to clean it. While he is inside scraping, Peronella positions herself at the mouth of the vat, blocking his view, and the lover emerges from under the coop to have sexual relations with her. An ass accidentally steps on the lover's fingers, causing him to cry out. Pietro discovers the lover. His wife, undaunted, verbally chastises him for his own neglect and effeminacy. Pietro, realizing he is outwitted and more interested in his own "lewd ends," makes peace with her, allowing her freedom as long as she is discreet.

**Elisa's Story (Seventh Day, Third Story): Fra Rinaldo**
Elisa tells of Fra Rinaldo, a young Siennese friar, who desires his "gossip" (godmother by spiritual kinship) Madam Agnesa, a married lady. He uses the excuse of being her child's godfather to gain access and eventually persuades her to lie with him. One day, her husband returns unexpectedly while Rinaldo is with her. Agnesa, quick-witted, tells her husband that Fra Rinaldo is "conjuring worms" from their child, who had a sudden fainting fit. She claims only the mother can be present and that Fra Rinaldo's comrade is upstairs performing other orisons. The husband, a simple man, believes her. Fra Rinaldo, having heard everything, emerges with the child, claiming it is healed. The husband is relieved and grateful, and Fra Rinaldo and Agnesa continue their affair under the guise of spiritual guidance.

**Lauretta's Story (Seventh Day, Fourth Story): Tofano**
Lauretta recounts how Tofano, a jealous husband in Arezzo, has a beautiful wife, Ghita. She, tired of his unfounded jealousy, takes a lover. To meet him, she encourages Tofano to drink until he is drunk. One night, Tofano feigns drunkenness to test her. She leaves. He locks her out. When she returns, he confronts her. She threatens to drown herself in a nearby well, then drops a large stone into it, making a splash. Tofano, believing she has jumped, rushes out to save her. Ghita slips back into the house, locks him out, and then taunts him from the window, shouting to neighbors that he is drunken and comes home late. The neighbors side with Ghita, and her kinsmen beat Tofano. Ashamed, Tofano makes peace with Ghita, allowing her freedom as long as she is discreet.

**Fiammetta's Story (Seventh Day, Fifth Story): Madam Beatrice**
Fiammetta tells of Madam Beatrice, wife of Messer Egano de' Gulluzzi of Bologna, who is loved by her husband's Florentine servant, Lodovico (disguised as Anichino). She discovers his love and returns it. Her husband, Egano, is very jealous. To meet her lover, Beatrice tells her husband that Anichino has tried to seduce her and has arranged a meeting in the garden at the foot of a pine tree that night. She suggests Egano disguise himself in her gown and veil and go in her place to test Anichino's loyalty. Egano, a simple man, agrees. He goes to the garden. Anichino, after making love to Beatrice, is instructed by her to take a cudgel to the garden and beat Egano (mistaking him for Beatrice) for tempting him. Anichino does so, shouting reproaches at Egano for being a "wicked woman." Egano, beaten, retreats, believing Anichino is loyal. Beatrice and Anichino continue their affair.

**Pampinea's Story (Seventh Day, Sixth Story): Madam Isabella**
Pampinea recounts how Madam Isabella, a noble Florentine lady, takes a lover, Leonetto, and is also coerced into an affair with Messer Lambertuccio, a powerful gentleman she dislikes. One day, at her country estate, her husband is away, and she is with Leonetto. Suddenly, Lambertuccio arrives. Isabella quickly hides Leonetto behind the bed curtains. She receives Lambertuccio. While they are together, her husband unexpectedly returns. Isabella quickly tells Lambertuccio to draw his dagger, go downstairs, and leave the house angrily, threatening to find someone elsewhere. Lambertuccio complies. Her husband, seeing Lambertuccio leave furiously, asks Isabella what happened. She fabricates a story of Lambertuccio pursuing an unknown youth into her house. Her husband believes her and then chivalrously escorts Leonetto (who emerges trembling from his hiding place) back to Florence. Isabella continues her affairs.

**Filomena's Story (Seventh Day, Seventh Story): Lodovico and Beatrice**
Filomena tells of Lodovico, a noble Florentine, who, hearing of the beautiful Madam Beatrice of Bologna, wife of Messer Egano de' Gulluzzi, travels there and takes service with Egano under the name Anichino. Beatrice, initially unaware of his love, begins to notice and like him. One day, playing chess, Anichino confesses his love. Beatrice, moved, returns his affection and promises to meet him that night. To do so, she tells her husband, Egano, that Anichino has confessed his love and arranged a tryst under a pine tree in the garden. She suggests Egano disguise himself as her to test Anichino's loyalty. Egano agrees. He goes to the garden. Anichino, after a passionate night with Beatrice, is instructed by her to take a cudgel to the garden and beat Egano (mistaking him for Beatrice). Anichino beats Egano severely, shouting reproaches. Egano, battered, returns, believing Anichino is loyal. Beatrice and Anichino continue their affair.

**Neifile's Story (Seventh Day, Eighth Story): Arriguccio Berlinghieri and Madam Sismonda**
Neifile recounts Arriguccio Berlinghieri, a jealous Florentine merchant, who closely watches his wife, Sismonda. She takes a lover, Ruberto. To meet him, she ties a thread to her great toe, running out her window to the street; Ruberto will tug it at midnight. One night, Arriguccio discovers the thread, cuts it, ties it to his own toe, and waits. Ruberto tugs. Arriguccio, armed, rushes out to confront him. They fight, but Ruberto escapes. Sismonda, realizing her husband knows, quickly persuades her maid to take her place in bed. Arriguccio returns, furious, and severely beats and cuts the maid's hair, believing it to be Sismonda. He locks her in and goes to tell Sismonda's brothers. Sismonda, meanwhile, arranges her bed and dresses as if she had not slept. Her brothers and mother arrive. Sismonda, seemingly unharmed, denies everything, blaming her husband's drunkenness and infidelity. The maid's disheveled state and cut hair are revealed, but Sismonda attributes it to Arriguccio's drunken violence on one of his own lovers. The brothers, believing Sismonda and angered by Arriguccio's perceived depravity, beat him. Arriguccio, shamed, makes peace with Sismonda, allowing her freedom as long as she is discreet.

**Pamfilo's Story (Seventh Day, Ninth Story): Lydia and Pyrrhus**
Pamfilo tells of Lydia, wife of Nicostratus of Argos, who falls in love with her husband's young servant, Pyrrhus. Pyrrhus, fearing a trick, demands three proofs of her love: she must kill her husband's prized hawk in his presence, send him a lock of her husband's beard, and send him one of her husband's teeth. Lydia cleverly accomplishes all three: she kills the hawk, claiming it stole her husband's attention; she pulls out a lock of his beard during playful wrestling; and she pulls out one of his teeth, claiming he has bad breath. Pyrrhus is convinced. Lydia then promises to lie with him in her husband's presence without him realizing. She takes Nicostratus and Pyrrhus to a pear tree in her garden. Pyrrhus climbs the tree and, from above, pretends to see Nicostratus and Lydia making love below. Nicostratus, disbelieving, climbs the tree himself, whereupon Lydia and Pyrrhus make love below. Nicostratus, from the tree, sees them and cries out. Pyrrhus climbs down and convinces Nicostratus that the tree is enchanted, making one see false visions. Lydia, feigning anger at the tree for shaming her, orders Pyrrhus to cut it down. Nicostratus, convinced, pardons them both, and Pyrrhus and Lydia continue their affair.

**King Dioneo's Story (Seventh Day, Tenth Story): Two Siennese and a Gossip**
King Dioneo tells of Tingoccio and Meuccio, two Siennese friends who vow that the first to die will return to report on the afterlife. Tingoccio falls in love with his "gossip" (godmother) Madam Mita, a beautiful married lady, and Meuccio also desires her. Tingoccio becomes Mita's lover. He later dies. Three days after his death, Tingoccio's ghost appears to Meuccio, telling him about purgatory. Meuccio asks about the punishment for sleeping with a gossip. Tingoccio replies that in the afterlife, "no manner of account is taken of gossips." Meuccio, hearing this, realizes his own past simplicity in refraining from such liaisons and resolves to be wiser in the future.

At the end of the seventh day, Dioneo's story causes laughter. Lauretta is appointed the new queen.
