He asks who they are. They bend their necks, and their tears freeze their eyes shut. They clash like enraged goats. One (CCamicion de' Pazzi), whose ears are reft by the cold, asks why the narrator speculates. He identifies himself as Camicione and his companion as two brothers from the Bisenzio valley, sons of Alberto (Alessandro and Napoleone degli Alberti). He says no one in Caina is more worthy of congealment, not even Focaccia or Mascheroni. He awaits his kinsman Carlino, whose deep guilt will wash out his own. The narrator sees a thousand doggish grins. As they move towards the middle, the narrator accidentally kicks a head. The spirit cries out, asking if he seeks revenge for Montaperti. The narrator, wanting to resolve his doubt, asks the spirit who he is. The spirit (Bocca degli Abati) retorts, asking who the narrator is, roaming Antenora. The narrator says he is living and can give him fame. Bocca says he desires the opposite. The narrator seizes his hair and pulls out tufts. Another spirit cries, "What ails thee, Bocca? Barkest thou outright?" Bocca, silenced, replies, "Tell what thou list; but as thou escape from hence to speak of him whose tongue hath been so glib, forget not: here he wails the Frenchman's gold." He identifies him as Buoso da Duera. He also points out Beccaria, Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello. They move on. The narrator sees two spirits frozen in one hollow, one's head a cowl to the other. The uppermost (Count Ugolino) gnaws the other's brain (Archbishop Ruggieri). The narrator asks the cause of such hate, promising to repay him in the world above if his grievance is just.

**Canto XXXIII:** The gnawing sinner (Count Ugolino) wipes his jaws on the mangled head and begins to speak. He says the narrator's request makes him relive sorrow. He will speak and weep to bring eternal infamy to the traitor he gnaws, Archbishop Ruggieri. He recounts how Ruggieri, through ill thoughts, imprisoned and murdered him. He describes a small grate (called the Tower of Famine) where he saw several moons pass. He had an evil dream: Ruggieri hunting a wolf and its whelps (Ugolino and his sons) in the mountains with lean hounds (Lanfranchi, Sismondi, Gualandi). He saw the tusks gore their sides. He awoke to his sons crying for bread. He describes his own stony silence, his sons' weeping, and little Anslem asking, "Father what ails thee?" He remained silent for a day and night. When a faint beam entered the prison, he saw his own image in his sons' faces and bit his hands in agony. His sons, thinking he bit from hunger, offered their own flesh. He kept his spirit still. They were silent for two more days. On the fourth day, Geddo died at his feet. Between the fifth and sixth day, the other three sons died one by one. Then, blind, he groped over them for three days, calling their names, until "fasting got the mastery of grief." He then resumes gnawing the skull. The narrator curses Pisa for its lack of justice, wishing for Capraia and Gorgona to dam the Arno and drown its people. He argues that even if Ugolino betrayed castles, his children (Brigata, Ugaccione, and two gentle ones) were too young to be guilty. They move on. Others are reversed in ice, weeping, but their tears freeze, increasing their anguish. The narrator feels a wind and asks Virgil about it, as he thought all vapor was quenched. Virgil replies they will soon see the cause. One spirit (Friar Alberigo) cries out, asking them to remove the hardened veil from his face so he can vent his grief. The narrator promises aid if he reveals his identity. Alberigo identifies himself as Friar Alberigo, who plucked "evil fruitage" and is repaid with "luscious fig" here. The narrator exclaims, "Art thou too dead!" Alberigo explains that Ptolomea (this region of hell) has the privilege of receiving souls even before their bodies die. A fiend takes possession of the betrayer's body, which then lives on earth until its appointed time, while the soul falls here. He says the narrator knows another ghost (Branca Doria) who winters here, though he appears alive on earth. The narrator expresses disbelief, saying Branca Doria still eats, drinks, and sleeps. Alberigo explains that Branca Doria left a demon in his stead in his own body, and so did a kinsman who wrought treachery with him. Alberigo asks the narrator to open his eyes. The narrator refuses, saying "Ill manners were best courtesy to him." The narrator curses Genoese for their foulness, noting Branca Doria is in Cocytus in soul, yet seems alive in body.

**Canto XXXIV:** Virgil points out "Hell's Monarch" (Lucifer) and his banners approaching. The narrator sees what resembles a windmill in the distance. He hides behind Virgil. They arrive where souls are whelmed transparent under ice, some prone, upright, or arched. Virgil makes the narrator pause and points out Dis (Lucifer), telling him to arm his heart with strength. The narrator is frozen and faint, unable to describe his state. Lucifer is at mid-breast from the ice, taller than a giant. He has three faces: vermilion in front, wan and yellow on the right, and black on the left. Two enormous bat-like wings flap, producing three winds that freeze Cocytus. He weeps from six eyes, and bloody foam distills down three chins. Each mouth champs a sinner. The foremost is Judas, head within, feet without. The other two, heads under, are Brutus (writhing, speechless) and Cassius. Virgil says night re-ascends, and it's time to go. The narrator clasps Virgil's neck. Virgil descends, stepping between the shaggy fell and jagged ice. At the point where the thigh turns on the haunches, Virgil painfully turns himself around, grappling the fell as one who mounts, making the narrator think they are returning to hell. Virgil, panting, explains this is the way to depart from extreme evil. They emerge at a rocky opening. The narrator expects to see Lucifer with legs downward, but sees him with legs upward. He wonders how he passed the center of the earth. Virgil explains that they were on the other side of the center until he turned, and then they crossed the point where all heavy substance is dragged. They are now in the opposite hemisphere, where morning rises when it is evening in the narrator's world. Lucifer fell from heaven to this part, and the earth recoiled, forming the seas in the narrator's hemisphere. Virgil explains a hidden way, discovered not by sight but by the sound of a brooklet, winds along a rock. By that hidden way, they exit, climbing without repose. They eventually see the "beautiful lights of heav'n" through a circular opening, and "again beheld the stars."

**PURGATORY**

**Canto I:** The narrator, having left the "cruel sea" of Hell, now begins his account of Purgatory, a region where the human spirit is purged for Heaven. He sees a serene sky of eastern sapphire and four bright stars never seen before by humans (save the "first parents"). He then encounters an old man, Cato of Utica, who questions their escape from "th' eternal prison-house" and whether the statutes of the abyss are broken. Virgil makes the narrator show reverence. Virgil explains that a "Dame from heaven" (Beatrice) dispatched him to rescue the narrator, who had strayed near damnation. He has shown the narrator Hell and now intends to show him the spirits purged from sin. He appeals to Cato by the love for his chaste Marcia, asking permission to pass through the seven regions, promising to thank Marcia in the upper world. Cato, bound by a different law since leaving Hell, agrees only because a heavenly dame sent them. He instructs Virgil to gird the narrator with a slender reed and lave his face with dew to remove the "sordid stain," as it would be unseemly to appear before the angel at the gate. He directs them to the reed-covered oozy bed near the water. Cato disappears. Virgil and the narrator descend to the plain, where Virgil washes the narrator's face with dew and girds him with a reed. Wherever a reed is plucked, another immediately springs up.

**Canto II:** The sun is at Jerusalem's meridian. They linger by the water. A swift light approaches over the sea, which Virgil identifies as "God’s angel." He instructs the narrator to kneel, as this angel needs no oars or sails, using only his eternal wings. The angel, visibly blessed, lands a small bark carrying over a hundred spirits. They sing "In Exitu Israel de Aegypto." The angel blesses them, and they leap ashore, then he returns as swiftly as he came. The new spirits, astounded, ask for directions to the mountain. Virgil replies they are also strangers, having arrived by a rougher road. The spirits realize the narrator is alive and are amazed, flocking around him. One spirit, Casella, rushes to embrace the narrator. The narrator attempts to embrace the shadow three times. Casella smiles and asks why the narrator is there. The narrator explains he journeys to return to a better life and asks why Casella is late. Casella explains the angel takes whom he chooses, and he has only recently been granted passage from the Tiber's mouth. The narrator asks Casella to sing a sweet love song. Casella sings "Love that discourses in my thoughts," delighting all. The old man (Cato) then scolds the "tardy spirits" for loitering, urging them to run to the mountain. The spirits hasten away, and the narrator and Virgil depart with hurried steps.

**Canto III:** The spirits scatter towards the mountain. The narrator stays close to Virgil, who seems smitten with self-remorse. The narrator notices the sun's rays are broken by his body. Nick Carraway, a young man from the Middle West, moves to West Egg, Long Island, in the spring of 1922 to learn the bond business. He rents a modest house situated next to a colossal mansion belonging to the enigmatic Jay Gatsby.

Nick visits his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, former football star husband, Tom Buchanan, at their opulent home in fashionable East Egg. Tom is portrayed as arrogant and physically imposing. At dinner, they are joined by Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During the evening, Tom receives a phone call, which Jordan reveals to Nick is from Tom's mistress in New York. Daisy, visibly upset, expresses cynical views, confessing her hope that her three-year-old daughter will grow up to be a "beautiful little fool." Jordan mentions Gatsby's name, sparking Daisy's curiosity. Later, Nick sees Gatsby standing alone on his lawn, stretching his arms toward a distant green light across the bay, which Nick identifies as the light at the end of Daisy's dock.

Tom takes Nick to New York, stopping in the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial area between West Egg and the city. There, they visit George B. Wilson's run-down garage. Wilson is a "spiritless" man, and his wife, Myrtle, is Tom's mistress. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle in New York. In the city, Myrtle changes into an elaborate dress, buys a dog, and takes Tom and Nick to a small apartment she shares with Tom. More guests arrive: Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and Mr. and Mrs. McKee. Catherine reveals a rumor that Gatsby is a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm and that he gets his money from this connection. She also confides that neither Tom nor Myrtle can stand their spouses and wish to marry each other, but Daisy is supposedly Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce (a lie, Nick notes). Myrtle recounts how she met Tom and her regret over marrying Wilson. As the evening progresses, fueled by alcohol, Myrtle taunts Tom by repeatedly shouting "Daisy!" Tom, in a fit of rage, strikes her and breaks her nose. Nick leaves with Mr. McKee.

Nick attends one of Gatsby's famous, lavish parties. He is one of the few invited guests and feels out of place among the many uninvited revelers who spread rumors about Gatsby's past (e.g., that he killed a man or was a German spy). Nick meets Jordan Baker there, and they encounter a drunk man in Gatsby's library, dubbed "Owl Eyes," who is surprised to find Gatsby's books are real. Later, Nick converses with a man who reveals himself to be Gatsby. Gatsby is a young, elegant man, not the older, corpulent figure Nick expected. Gatsby is called away by a phone call. Jordan tells Nick that Gatsby claims to be an Oxford man, but she doesn't believe him. Jordan then hints at "the most amazing thing" she learned from Gatsby but refuses to reveal it. As Nick leaves, he witnesses a car crash outside Gatsby's mansion, involving the "Owl Eyes" man as a passenger.

One morning, Gatsby visits Nick and invites him to lunch in New York. Gatsby attempts to tell Nick about his past, claiming to be the son of wealthy, deceased Middle Westerners, educated at Oxford, a war hero with medals (which he shows Nick), and a world traveler. In New York, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler with human molar cufflinks, who reveals he "made" Gatsby and that Gatsby fixed the 1919 World's Series. Tom Buchanan then appears in the restaurant, and Gatsby mysteriously vanishes after being introduced.

As Tom, Nick, and Jordan drive back to Long Island in Tom's coupé, they encounter an accident in the valley of ashes. Myrtle Wilson has been struck by a car and killed. Michaelis, a coffee shop owner, witnessed Myrtle run into the road. Other witnesses describe the car as a "big yellow car. New." Wilson, distraught, overhears this and declares he knows what kind of car it was. Tom, realizing Wilson suspects the yellow car (Gatsby's), quickly tells Wilson that the yellow car he was driving earlier wasn't his and that he just arrived from New York in his blue coupé, deflecting suspicion from himself. Tom weeps in the car, calling the hit-and-run driver a "coward."

Back at the Buchanan's, Nick sees Tom and Daisy sitting together, not happy but with an "unmistakable air of natural intimacy," conspiring. Gatsby, who had been waiting outside the house to ensure Daisy's safety, confesses to Nick that Daisy was driving his yellow car when she hit Myrtle. He explains Daisy was nervous and wanted to drive, and Myrtle ran out into the road, possibly thinking it was Tom's car. Gatsby claims he will take the blame. Nick urges Gatsby to go home and get some sleep, but Gatsby insists on waiting all night, watching Daisy's house.

The next morning, Nick visits Gatsby, urging him to leave because his car will be traced. Gatsby refuses, saying he cannot leave Daisy until he knows what she will do. Gatsby shares more details of his past, revealing he was a penniless officer when he met Daisy and let her believe he was from her wealthy class, taking her under "false pretences." He admits he was committed to a "grail" in his pursuit of her. He recounts their original love and his desperate return to Louisville when she married Tom, feeling he had lost the "freshest and the best" part of his life. Gatsby still believes Daisy truly loves him.

The gardener announces he is draining the pool, but Gatsby tells him to wait, as he has never used it. Nick prepares to leave for the city, but delays, feeling a bond with Gatsby. As he finally departs, Nick shouts across the lawn, "They’re a rotten crowd... You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together." Gatsby smiles radiantly.

Nick attempts to work in the city. Jordan Baker calls, saying she has left Daisy's house and their relationship is over. Nick tries to call Gatsby but his line is busy, held for a long-distance call from Detroit. Nick learns that Gatsby's business dealings are being investigated.

Meanwhile, Michaelis returns to Wilson's garage. Wilson, still distraught, begins to talk about the yellow car and reveals that Myrtle had come home bruised months ago, leading him to believe she had a secret life. Looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg billboard, Wilson states, "God sees everything," believing God will reveal the killer. Wilson then disappears. His movements are traced to West Egg, where he asks for directions to Gatsby's house.

At 2 PM, Gatsby puts on his bathing suit and goes to the pool, having told his butler to bring any phone calls there. The chauffeur heard gunshots. Nick arrives at Gatsby's house and, with the chauffeur, butler, and gardener, finds Gatsby's body floating in the pool. The gardener then discovers Wilson's body in the grass nearby. The "holocaust was complete."

In the aftermath, police and reporters swarm Gatsby's house. At the inquest, Catherine, Myrtle's sister, falsely testifies that Myrtle never knew Gatsby and was happy with Wilson, simplifying the case to Wilson being "deranged by grief." Nick feels responsible for Gatsby, as no one else seems to care. He calls Daisy, but she and Tom have left town without a trace. Nick tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, who refuses to get involved, expressing shock but claiming business obligations. Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, a solemn old man. He shows Nick Gatsby's childhood schedule and "General Resolves" from a book, revealing Gatsby's early ambition.

At Gatsby's funeral, only Nick, Mr. Gatz, the Lutheran minister, a few servants, and the "Owl Eyes" man attend. Nick is dismayed by the lack of attendees, especially Tom and Daisy. The "Owl Eyes" man remarks, "The poor son-of-a-bitch."

Nick decides to return West. He breaks off his relationship with Jordan Baker, who accuses him of carelessness. Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan in New York. Tom confesses he told Wilson who owned the yellow car, claiming Wilson was crazed and deserved what happened, and that Myrtle's death was a hit-and-run. Nick realizes that Tom and Daisy are "careless people"—they "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness... and let other people clean up the mess they had made." Nick leaves Tom, disgusted.

Gatsby's house stands empty. Nick visits it one last time before leaving. He reflects on Gatsby's pursuit of Daisy, which was tied to the green light at the end of her dock. Gatsby's dream of the future had always been just out of reach, eventually becoming part of the past. Nick concludes that "we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

**Book I: The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon**

Achilles calls a council, where the prophet Chalcas, encouraged by Achilles' promise of protection, reveals that Apollo's rage is due to Agamemnon's refusal to release Chryseïs. Agamemnon is compelled to return his captive but, enraged, enters into a furious contest with Achilles, threatening to take Briseïs from him. Nestor attempts to pacify them, advising Agamemnon not to seize Achilles' prize and Achilles not to contend with a king. Despite Nestor's efforts, Agamemnon, exercising his supreme command, seizes Briseïs from Achilles.

In discontent, Achilles withdraws himself and his Myrmidon forces from the Greek army. He complains to his mother, Thetis, who supplicates Jupiter (Jove) to honor her son by granting victory to the Trojans until the Greeks realize their wrong against Achilles. Jupiter grants her suit, which incenses Juno. A high debate ensues between them, eventually reconciled by Vulcan, who reminds them of his own past suffering at Jove's hands.

This book covers 22 days: nine days of plague, one day for the council and quarrel, and twelve days for Jupiter's absence with the Æthiopians before Thetis presents her petition.
